pros:
- The technology.
 - The people.
 - The IT.
 - The salary.
 - Restaurant card, transport card, private health insurance.
 - 100% remote.
 - 100% English.
cons:
- The mentoring program: make sure your mentor is from your team.
 - The mentoring program: follow blindly and only what your mentor says, even if it conflicts with your team's interests. Otherwise, you will get fired no matter you do next. 
 - I was not interviewed by my team or leader, but by other team's. Therefore, when I entered my actual team, the conditions were different. For example:
 - In the interview, I asked if they followed scrum or any agile methodology. They said yes. Turned out to be a complete lie.
Advice to Management
- Terrible local management: they hire people in the most stressful stages of development and in July/August when offices are in vacation. They, therefore, have no resources to teach, lead or mentor you. It ends up with you fired because you failed their broken mentoring system goals.

review_title: Looks for cheap labour Ericsson Ireland
pros:
- Hires from outside Ireland
- Sponsors visa
- Good work-life balance
- Colleagues are helpful
- If you are lucky you would get to work on latest technologies
cons:
This review is for Ericsson Ireland
- Hires from outside Ireland with low compensation. It's a win-win condition though if you are looking for work permit sponsorship only.
- They don't care about past experiences of the employees. If you are experienced with cutting edge cloud technology, you may get into old monolith application.
- Your career growth also doesn't depend on your past experiences. You may have to learn the legacy technologies again which you probably left 5 years back and have to prove yourself again.
- Promotion is a myth unless you can have good relationship with your manager. You may see other less competent people are getting promoted.
- Compensation is the last thing would like discuss with your friends who works in other companies. You may get half salary than that of your friends but manager will convince you that you are earning above Ericsson standard.
- Because of the above reasons lots of good employees are leaving the company.
- It's getting long, so I'm cutting it down here :)
Advice to Management
- Respect the experience and knowledge of your employees.
- Increase compensation.
- Get rid of the fatty layers in leadership and promote eligible ones.
- I believe you have the quality to retain good people.

Helpful

pros:
Good 401k, Medical and Vacation Benefits.
Lots of vacations to maintain a healthy balance.
cons:
While the overall company has a good culture, Austin site doesn't have the culture what Sweden has. Even though projects have long durations teams struggle to get things done on time, and then politics starts with blame games.
Very bad tools and infrastructure. Every other day you will login and not be able to work as infra would be hung or super slow.
Its more of a bootlicking culture where people who are close to leads get all the career growth.
Teams are technically poor with no understanding of underlying technology, its just blind execution. There is neither depth nor breadth in the work, its about writing some tests, no real development work is there in Austin.
All the technical interesting work stays in Sweden.
Line management is pretty much useless with no technical skills and no drive to improve things. They just write some politically correct emails.
Anyone who is good leaves the place in 6months to about a 1-1.5 years time frame at max.
In short no learning and growth, if you want to kill your career sure come here.

pros:
I have been working now 2 years in Ericsson. The best thing I like about Ericsson is the transparency from management. Be it Bad or Good. They share both. This enhance the confidence of the employees.
The next thing I can speak is about the caring nature of the Company. The top management really values all employees and their wellbeing. During this pandemic they thought about the general challenges faced by us employees for Working From Home. They tried their best to keep us well both physically and mentally. Starting from WiFi Bills to proper furniture for working. Ericsson gave us everything we need.
Work Life Balance is generally there. Though it depends on the customers and Project. But, on long term Yes it is there.
Number of Paid Holidays is one of the best in the industry. As per the Company’s policy you will be entitled to 12 days Casual Leave and 25 days of Privilege/ Earned Leaves. These will be pro-rated in case you join any time during the year. The Company also provides 12 festival / public holidays including national holidays.
If you have to work on any holiday then they pay you 2*Normal day payment. If you need to work on National Holiday then they pay you 3* Normal day Payment. This is a very good policy for cases where we are bound to work on Holidays due to any urgent work.
cons:
Salary Revisions are less for higher Compare Ratio people. Suppose you join Ericsson with already a high package as per your designation then you will get less % appraisals till your next promotion. After promotion you would get good hikes though. But, till then you have to manage with single digit % hikes.
Advice to Management
It would be great if Salary Revisions are bit more for more eligible employees at least even if the Compare Ratio is above 100 %. This would prevent Brain Drain from Ericsson. Please give a serious thought about it.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Great company, great people and awesome experiences, but not a great outlook.
pros: Opportunities to work with people all over the world, and grow your career in different areas so you're always learning.
cons:
Unable to break out of core business and expand beyond mobile operator customer base despite continuous attempts. Our customers are our lifeblood and our greatest threat at the same time as the industry is commoditized. After 5G, OpenRAN will take over and the revenues will continue to decline unless new business is unlocked.
Advice to Management
Be willing to break ties with our customers and make bigger bets on the future. If we can't break the shackles we will slowly contract as a business.

review_title: DC Market - Great, FL Market - Lacked Organization
pros:
DC Market : Great leadership in place, you know what you're doing for the week ahead of time. Work meetings held on a monthly basis to go over progress. They take care of their own. Great work-life balance

FL Market : Multiple builds going on at the same time.
cons:
DC Market : Lack of fleet vehicles to go around.

FL Market: Impossible deadlines, work-life balance seemingly non-existent. Constant travel statewide. Management will blame you for everything.
Advice to Management
Instead of laying people off, hire more personnel so deadlines can be met and assign tower crews to certain regions of the state so they can be relatively closer to home and not have to charge for hotels (this will save the company money and allow the tower crew to go home more often to be with family).

pros:
1) Ericsson provides great medical, retirement and other benefits that small companies may not afford or have access.
2) For the first 2 years, there will be a lot of debate how to integrate your products/new business into the larger company, so changes to the every day activities will be minimal.
3) Access to a large number of global positions (although limited now due to Covid restrictions)
4) There are a lot of opportunities to integrate with other portfolios if you have a clear business differentiator.
cons:
If your business was acquired to eliminate competition, expect drastic staff reductions and project be closed after negotiating end of life with previous customers.
Advice to Management
After an acquisition do not underestimate the role and function of a site manager. Their role is to keep a development site relevant and keep migrating staff from one product closing to a new one opening.

review_title: Niche Industry. Not suitable for every one.
pros:
1. Work culture is Good
2. Fellow Employees and Managers alike are very down to earth and very approachable.
3. Lots of customer facing projects
4. There are some Open Source projects as well.
5. Open source projects use modern languages like python and go.
6. Internal movement between projects happen frequently.
cons:
1. Lack of exciting projects.
2. Pay is on the lower side given it is a service based company.
3. For those looking for coding projects there is a scarcity of those kind of projects.
4. It is a telecom industry, so not suited for all. Its a niche industry.
5. Stretch projects and assignments can be challenging especially where there is no monetary benefit given.

cons:

Advice to Management
People in middle management are not only looking for monetary results, money is important but people also look for job rotation, opportunity to get into decision making roles. any one who is top performer for 4 to 5 yrs back to back should not be doing same roles and should be given bigger roles..

pros:
Excellent work life balance (common in Sweden)
Sustainability focused
Good technology leadership
There is a job for you somewhere in the company and it's easy to change to totally new roles
cons:
Extremely bureaucratic; can be hard to make an impact in your first few years at the company. Trust is earned, not given from the start.

Often feels very "old school" in terms of top down authority driven management practices.

Diversity is lacking, especially in senior and key tech positions
Advice to Management
Hire in / promote more diversity and, most importantly, when you get the people in, SUPPORT them: help them navigate the complex Swedish cultural rules, set clear expectations on what success looks like in the role, ask them what they need to be successful and realize it may mean breaking the long established organizational rules.

pros: You can do nothing and still have the same performance review as others working hard, because Line Managers (a weird role which does not work with you but manages you) doesn't want to do their work.
cons:
Too many, below average salary, totally in-transparent management but always talking about transparency, non-stop re-organizing (annually or semi-annually), no accountability (kept making wrong decisions or performing bad but no consequence), no incentive mechanism (refer to pros), endless new processes, discrimination (Swedish gets promotion most time even they know very little or nothing about what they'll take responsibility), lying, etc.
Advice to Management
They won't do for sure but I suggest most of them resign immediately, because most of them only care about how to satisfy their managers without bottom line then pass pressure to line members and seek for next point to please upper management. So these people will give promise to everything requested by upper managers, then fail those tasks (or with much lower quality/quantity results) but without any consequence (refer to cons), and get promoted later because of their goodness at "execution".

review_title: Worst company to be a part of. I worked in EGIL Ericsson Global Private Limited.
pros: The only pro i can think of was free green tea during cofee breaks.
cons:
1. Pays sub par salary to talented undergraduates which literally destroys their self-esteem. Also if one's exposure is to such a company as a fresher mostly people will go into depression. As many of my friends did. I left the company as soon as the bond period was over. 
2, Before one joins as a fresher they make us sign a bond of 1.5 years with a package of 2.7 Lakhs per annum which is nothing when compared to other companies, even it is below average if you want to make a livelihood as middle class man. 
3. Gruelling shifts of morning, evening and night which literally is inhumane. If you join ericsson just forget about work life balance and anything related to balance may it be physical or mental.
Advice to Management
I literally have no advice because anyways they don't follow advices and just focus on cost cutting. Well, what can we expect from a management which lacks innovation or skills. Instead of making better products they are only focused on cutting costs which increase their profitability. A typical example of Indian managers pleasing their Swedesh countrparts not by doing something constructive but by enslaving their Indian brethren.

pros:
- Work life balance (though it might vary based on your respective team)

- Product based, so there is relatively higher job safety compared to project-based companies

- Overall professional work environment (atleast superficially)

- Cab and shuttles available

- Annual Product Release parties
cons:
- Vertical hierarchy. Not good chances to take a vertical leap, if you're planning to. Opportunities are less and people are too many. 

- Favoritism is a key role as with any other place. Do not go in with expectations of people being fair to you. Mostly, only people in good books of managers get all big opportunities like onsite trips and all. If you are used to doing only good work, expect yourself to be used as a placeholder more or less. 

- Voice review: There is a voice review where employees get to rate their managers. Although a potentially good tool, still it becomes a pain in all possible areas. Because some select few managers force their teams to rate them 5/5 on every question of the review. Some even take their teams in meeting rooms and force them to fill out the review in person to ensure that they are rated high. If the company wants to utilize the efficacy of this tool, they must ensure the integrity behind it, as well. Be strict and give your employees the leverage to reach out and complain against managers who are forcing them. Managers should be strictly warned, as well.

- Negativity: Though negativity exists everywhere, still it is a different ballgame here altogether. There are very negative people who will compel you to leave the company at earliest. They will poison your ears against job security and what not. Beware of them at all costs. Such people will force you to leave and they will still remain intact at their positions in the company even after 10+ years.

- Visibility can be a big issue if you want to get noticed for your work. Since it's a big company, you will have to do pretty novel things to get the limelight.

- Appraisals are not good. So, if you join, make sure you are joining after a good hike already. Do not expect your salary to increase through appraisals. It's just for the process sake. Hardly anything happens in terms of compensation. 

- Your manager is basically your company here. So, if you have a manager who prefers bootlickers to actual workers, backbiters to straight forward people, ego-massagers to go getters, then you will have a tough time growing. And trust me, when I say, the company is ridden to the core with such people. There are plethora of managers who just want their personal pawns in their teams. If you have such a manager, you will have to play your cards well in order to grow. Because there are many people to ego-massage the manager if you're not willing to. And they are the ones who get all the opportunities, especially the big ones.

- Third party contractors: Do not join on third party payroll unless you have no other option whatsoever. Since managers are given a lot of power in this company, your equation with your manager becomes the most important aspect here. In all honesty, I have observed third party contractors being disrespected and ill-treated several times not just by their own managers but by random people on the floor. Third party contractors are given trouble for very basic things, such as laptops, monitors, keyboards, and others.
Advice to Management
- Be strict against managers who are forcing their employees to rate them high on voice reviews. 

- Employees should be provided with a safe environment where they don't feel threatened or intimidated. Managers take the liberty to insult anyone they like, whenever they like. There are no repercussions, and hence, they continue doing it without inhibitions.

- Managers are given too much power. They should also be monitored accordingly and held accountable for their actions.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: It's okay, if you don't mind the chaos and the lower wage
pros:
- Comfortable work environment
- Employees are respected
- Good work / life balance
cons:
- Management chaos, both technical and non-technical
- Slim paycheck due to low-wage telco industry
- No separation of responsibilities (everyone does everything)
Advice to Management
Take a look at how more successful IT companies do software development. For example how do these more successful companies define and separate responsibilities. In my experience having everyone do everything only results in chaos. It would take an archwizzard to single-handedly do all of the following: agile event orchestration, project administration, feature planning, requirement handling, architecture design, software development, quality assurance, CI/CD, documentation, customer support. Yet this is exactly what is expected from a simple developer at Ericsson.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Meaningful work, excellent exposure to technology, great colleagues
pros: Interesting work, get to work across the technology stack , great colleagues, reasonable additional benefit package - pension, healthcare, sick leave.
cons:
Salary is below industry average. Career progression can be difficult as heavily dependent on being networked to right people, and hard to break through to that circle.
Advice to Management
Encourage more speaking out and listen to it. Give more opportunity to people who don't fit your mould - break out ... you are diverse in terms of people from different countries and cultures but not in terms of truly encouraging diversity of opinion about strategy and execution. 
There is a lot of lip service to speaking out but in reality it is not appreciated and can hurt career opportunities. You need to 'unbutton'.

pros: Worked at Ericsson , Gurgaon (India). Work Life balance is fine though at times there can be more work pressure. Leaves are not much a problem. Work from home is working fine. Learning totally depends in what project you are going.
cons:
HR is not that good. Learning is not much if you go in old project. Average hikes of 6-7 percent. Early exit from the company is very very difficult. Also during exit, sometimes they not at all consider wear and tear in laptops considering work from home environment and charge a lot of bucks.
Advice to Management
Please improve. Consider early exit in urgency since 3 months notice period is too much anyways. Consider the wear and tear in laptops that can occur in wfh since not everyone has a proper office at home.

pros:
> Managable stress
> Colleagues help you to get familiar with the tech stack that you need to understand
> Sometimes your preference to work with a given technology or on a project is taken into consideration by the managerial circles.
> International business travels are possible however you need to be vigilant and it require a lot of organization on your part.
cons:
> Always check your payroll because anomalies do happen
> Many buzzwords and politics. It makes software people alienated.
> You need to develop coping mechanisms for situations where you are expected to deliver a solution with zero amount of actionable information.
> Software requirements usually riddled with buzzwords. 
> Agile development process with exact deadlines. You are expected to give an exact estimation for a problem that consist of buzzword riddled requirements. The peple who expect you to provide these estimates do not understand the requirements either.
> Poor requirement handling all together.
Advice to Management
Redefine Ericsson as a software company. Source code here sometimes treated literally as garbage and the people engineering it are on the bottom of the food pyramid. People are alienated from their work. I am not motivated to succeed mainly because that our projects are ill-defined.

review_title: Good starting company to get experience
pros:
Hands on newest technology, good growth opportunities.
Very Intelligent people to work with and learn from.
Good salaries even for starting grads.
Nice ergonomic desks and chairs and decent laptops.
cons:
The products change a lot and very fast, not enough context given on the products and their acronyms. Many of the engineers who already have a good grasp on said products is because they were there from the start.

Lots of stressful deadlines. Depending on the team, you could be either very busy or very relaxed.

Compared to other companies, the benefits could be better.

Not a lot of mental and healthcare support seen (especially during the pandemic)
Advice to Management
Facilitate and encourage transparent conversations among team members. 
Empower employees to take wellness breaks. 
Recognise the team members’ efforts and provide recognition, not just negative feedback.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

pros:
- Excellent work life balance
- After you've built strong integration skills, you have the opportunity to work on assignments almost anywhere in the world (at least pre-COVID)
- Competitive starting salary
- Weekly/daily Fika (Coffee meetup)
- Coursera/Pluralsight free memberships
cons:
- Telecom in general is super complicated and not easy to understand, people who do understand are always busy and not really open for communication
- Tools are not always the latest
- Skills learnt here might not be transferable other than the telecom sector
- People who have spent a long time here are too comfortable (in general, not all) and are hard to communicate to but this trend is changing gradually as Ericsson is hiring a lot of young skilled people lately

Repor

pros: Pay is good for the role, and for the location. Benefits and reward systems are also pretty good.
cons:
Each unit seems to have 1000 senior managers and only two people who actually do the work. Too many senior managers all wanting to only attend meetings give their opinions and dish out tasks. 
The company is also extremely reluctant to hirer new people even where the need may be crystal clear. Easy to get overworked while someone else gets a pat in the back for successfully cutting down budget costs. Have seen the best and most hardworking employees chased out of the company because of this (they cannot get support) leaving behind only the lazy ones who have already given up on the company.
Advice to Management
Whoever is is charge of allocating budget for new hires should have a one-on-one chat with the engineers who actually do the job (not the team leaders who sometimes have no idea what is going on). Don't punish the handworkers for being hardworking until you eventually drive them all out of the company. I have seen the best employees leave because of this, you will be left with the lazy ones who have already given up on any efficiency in the company.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros:
- Work environment is really great
- Company cares about well being of employees
- Managers inspire to take on different certifications
- Very flexible work hours
- Not so much of mental pressure from management
cons:
- Employees with lesser experience are sometimes hired for a senior post
- Pressure of taking on different certifications are sometimes too much to handle specially with the ongoing project goals
- Employeses are rarely awarded for their performance in projects due to lack of transparency between project managers and higher management.
- Salary revisions are often given on average basis, not performance-wise.
Advice to Management
- Employees contributing towards achieving company goals should be awarded.
- Scrutiny of employee performance should be implemented.
- To boost morale, promote some existing employees rather than hiring new employees with lesser experience for a senior post.

pros: Being part of a great company, with multiple job roles to choose from; the possibility of migrating on another department within the company.
cons:
Some managers have absolutely no skills related to people management. There is no transparency related to their decisions. There is no work volume quantification. The vacation days are approved only if you find another colleague willing to do your work also, while you are in vacation. At least this happens in Romania.
Advice to Management
Try to be opened to the problems raised by the team. It is absurd to work in a great Swedish company where line managers impose a North Korean atmosphere. If a manager receives a bad review in the Voice survey from multiple persons, try to have a one to one discussion instead of a all team meeting, because you will get more details and information in a private discussion.

review_title: Very good, could be much better
pros: My team was composed of a fantastic group of people. The working environment was excellent. Structured work environment, good team work, company was mature enough to have good tools and processes. The job itself was not difficult.
cons:
First impressions were not good. For those who are motivated, this is probably not the place for you. The company doesn't spend money on its employees. You are not given any responsibilities or goals. It's a good stepping stone or place to retire to. As with all large corporations, your career varies depending on what team you're working with.
Advice to Management
It wouldn't hurt to talk to your employees once in while.

pros: Since Ericsson is such a big organization, you can find internal opportunities in a vast number of roles.
cons:
Working at Ericsson is like being in Indian politics, its really bad. No matter how hard you work or whatever you achieve for the team or the organization the growth of the individual completely depends on you being in the good books of your manager by providing him inside information of the team and flattering him.
Advice to Management
Listen to your Engineers, they are the ones getting their hands dirty. Managers don't give you the full picture of whats really going on.

pros:
.Work life balance.
.Good bonus at least for my team.

.Terrible leadership like some gangster style group targeting people for being smart and open about their opinions.
.Have never heard or come across such weak set of people who are just cowards and insecure from intelligent people.
.Plus there is non quality work as almost all of the first batch of talented employees quit the team GAIA as I said they were bright ,intelligent and talented.
.To top it all there is a top guy in Blore (polished on exterior) who behaves like he is some sort of old king or slave owner and he actually has 3 slaves in reality in the firm and they just follow his whims and stupidities.

Don't think it's worth it.

pros: Strong benefits for US, very international culture, influential company. 5G will provide growth in the Networks division for some time.
cons:
Significant pay, rank disparities across company. Very easy in the US if you are on a Visa or are a woman to make significantly less than your peers. And the upper management is predominantly white, male, and Swedish. They are working hard to fix the gender disparities, but there is resulting age discrimination. And there is great job mobility if you start in Europe, but higher US wages reduce your options if you start there. If you are not in the Networks side of the business, you are not in a healthy business and are at risk.
Advice to Management
There are 10M people in Sweden. Half of those are men. Let's say 80% of them are white and 20% of the rest have at least a bachelors degree. That is a global talent pool of 800K for leadership positions in a company with 110K employees. It is bananas that you have not fixed this by 2020. There is no way that the shareholders are being served well by this restricted talent pool.
2 people found this review helpful

pros:
Best company for the people who are inspired for 4g 5g like telecom technology.
Day to day new challenges related to telecom technology of Ericsson product
Purely working on Ericsson product , it also includes Linux and Windows administration , Openstack.
For Telecom background people Ericsson is the best company to work with
cons:
Linux admin people should not join the company, the product runs on Linux but will not be working purely on linux.
To grow the career in ericsson must have best understanding of ericsson product.
Senior people are at high preferrence than fresher or people who have 4 years experience in Ericsson is more prefered than 7 years experienced recently joined employee.
NO overtime money is provided, if worked in weekend also will not provided totally depend on the project or client assigned.
Busy schedule. Need to support in weekend also without extra pay for weekend.
If there is career aspiration on Telecom related technology then and then only it is best

review_title: Excellent Place to start a career in Software
pros:
- Latest Technologies
- Lot of learning opportunities and trainings (a lot)
- Excellent work life balance (except for the occasional spikes)
- Social Activities, Events and SPSO (Ericsson Sports and Social)
- Canteen
- Location (Athlone, IRL)

cons:
- A bit slow on the career progression side
- Salary is a bit on the lower side
Advice to Management
You have an excellent site in Athlone. I believe you can improve employee retention a lot if you bump up the pay to the current day standards.

review_title: All that glitters is not gold.
pros: Good Salary for experienced and timely payout on the 25th of every month.
cons:
The post is an engineer and there is no engineering work.
Worst time management and shifts I have ever seen. Egoistic Managers. I have seen in my 1.5 Years of working with Ericsson - more than 32 Resignations and reason can be self-explained if you are planning to join this office.
No promotions until you give your more than 5 years and that too is luck depends on how much you praise and gossip with your manager and lead about your colleagues.
Work Likf balance is null.
Advice to Management
Take action and check the skills and the educational abilities of your managers who know even less than their team they are running. try to communicate with your junior employee's monthly basis and see if they are facing any issues with their egoistic superiors or not.

pros: Ericsson is a solid company with worldwide located offices. Having had the opportunity to visit most of those offices worlwide, I had the possibility to experience many different kind of WoW. Everywhere I went I found structured processes guiding the activities and projects, training plans, career paths and welcoming offices (people and premises). Ericsson gives a wide range of career development opportunities, it's much up to the employee to catch them!
cons:
IN the recent years many employees had to leave their job in the Company and this gave a slightly bad light to the company, in general. The decisions taken on who to keep onboard have not always been taken wisely causing, sometimes, very negative impacts on ongoing activities. While in the past (until 2015) the Company was very attentive to people as individuals, afterwards it became considering people more as numbers for the sake of the head count reduction. This was a big disappointment especially for the "old" employees
Advice to Management
Don't forget to consider the employees as people and individuals not only through slogans, big statements and Company picture for the press, but also in the real day to day life! Really!
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Very flexible but a bit low paying
pros:
Flexible work hours
Not stressful
Not too demanding
Opportunities to learn
Opportunities to grow
Good company culture
Diverse work
You can most probably work there until you retire, no fear of firing/layoffs.
cons:
Lower salary
Disorganized management/leadership
The higher you go, the more politics you encounter.
Your salary increase is based on your current salary, +10% per year is exceptional. If you go there as a student then eventually you will be underpaid if you don't lobby for a more significant salary increase.
Advice to Management
Hire more seniors.
Delegate project leadership on highly skilled or high potential developers/architects instead of overloading some people.
Specify less goals. Focus on the most important ones. Keep this up in the future.
Don't reorganize so much.
1 person found this review helpful

Don't go there if you would like to improve in your profession. There are many superfluous managers with strong power. It called matrix management. Salary is average. Bad atmosphere.
Advice to Management
Terminate the matrix management. Line managers are not needed at all. Pushing scrum is not solves everything. Improve your technical knowledge, and you will be able to manage a project.

5) My entire batch resigned within 2 years (mostly boys) I survived 3+ years due to patience . I don't know but every new joinee specially boys are considered as threat to managers and lead they start bullying them.
6)All show no go : Big PPT slides , even bigger roadmap but in reality they don't know where to start
7) unprofessional attitude of seniors : one who offers cigrattes or biryani usually get an edge over any hardworking employee
8) They will make you believe you are worthless
9) For shift allowances and holiday payout : Employess are fighting among themselves like rats and dogs

In short , If you really want to learn and grow and build a strong carrier never join Ericsson's kolkata location . Even if you have already done the mistake , build up your domain , make a strong CV and leave!!!
Advice to Management
Bring some people who actually know how to use the technical resources for delivery . I have seen test engineer getting hired as automation implementation lead

pros: Work-life balance, a lot of free time
cons:
Terrible ways of working. Everything is so slow, people compete with each other and ignore each others work in the same time. They try to invent a wheel over and over again. You will find little respect and little recognition, especially if you are young or if you are a woman and I suspect many other if's. Lack of management, and management is overall not qualified for such positions, managers are selected internally and usually people apply for management positions for a slightly better salary after being a researcher or engineer and having no interest in managing people. 

Top-management and employees are in two different worlds, people don't speak up here and don't have a right to be heard. They work here because they have kids, loans, cars and no will to take control of their life. They do patents for every sneeze, they are professional in creating nothing out of nothing. 

No work and no interesting projects. There are people working here for 20 years and they are completely brain-washed. They can sit and smile when everything is falling apart around them saying "Guys, we are doing great!".
Advice to Management
Just leave and let other people knowing how to do it come and manage.

review_title: Short review about my short abidance at Ericsson
pros: A complex range of activities, which imply a continuous communication strategy between departments, critical thinking and problem solving skills could be developed easily.
cons:
It depends very much on the project. The project where i worked, it was devoid of anything that stands for a training. I had to ask every single time for help from my colleagues, because the procedures for fault management of incidents were outdated. 
There was also a continuous flux of incoming calls from technicians across Spain, and there were only 3 or 4 persons assigned for a daily shift.
Advice to Management
They should focus more on proper trainings & workshops. All they care about is solving as many incidents in the agreed SLA.

review_title: Frustrating experience as a senior software engineer.
pros:
Reasonable work-life balance. 
Confortable environment.
cons:
Poor or no recognition for excellent work. 
Very low salaries, cost of living in Ireland is very high and the salaries doesn't keep up. 
All the products have very complex implementation, commonly over-engineered. Poor reuse of industry standard technologies, it has a tendency of creating things from scratch involving a lot o people with no experience.
Difficult to deal with many veteran staff, they have inflated egos and very frequently bad arguments, poor social skills, terrible leadership abilities. This includes senior engineers, master engineers and managers. 
Excess of bureaucracy for developing software. Agile is a facade that everyone pretends that is working fine.
Advice to Management
The turn over is extremely high because the company is terrible in recognizing people's work and potential. All the good employees that I know have left the company because of the low salary and the frustrated relationship with their line managers.

review_title: Ericsson in Plano, Texas is Horrible
pros: Beautiful campus, frequent events, process-oriented
cons:
Ericsson USA has lost its shine since mid 2011. They were under pressure to cut costs through offshoring. Engineers and solution architects were hired from India for fraction of the cost. As a result layoffs took place in the US especially when Ericsson’s profitability was questioned in 2017-2018. The Indian employees transferred to the US. Therefore, the company is now another Indian company with little to no Swedish influence. If you decide to join, do your homework of understanding what it is like to work in an Indian culture.
Advice to Management
The ship is sinking.

review_title: Good for graduates looking to get experience before landing a good paying job, don't stay past 2 years
pros: Cutting edge technology stacks, development follows best practices for software engineering, great place to go after graduating
cons:
Extremely bad pay, little to no job progression prospects, your experience there will greatly depend upon the manager(s) you have, when it's good, it's good but when it's bad, it's really bad
Advice to Management
Some of your managers have extremely high turnover, there's a reason for that. Listen to your employees when they report things. Investigate how employees with high reviews year in, year out suddenly get bad reviews and get put on personal performance plans which are basically a construed step to firing an employee that the manager doesn't like. Some manages are awesome but boy does 5 years going down the drain suck. Worked out for me and at least ten other employees in the same boat though, so I really should be grateful. Thanks!
3 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros:
There is a potential to work on really cool challenges - but be prepared to meet resistance.

Working in an R&D environment with 10.000's of users look really good on the CV
cons:
The culture of indifference. "We've always done it this way", could be the motto for the GIC program. Unsurprisingly this has led to a mess of an environment.

I think that a lot of it can be tracked down to skilled people leaving the company, and I think I will join them soon. Left are the people that doesn't really care. That doesn't bother to read up on how to solve an issue properly. That doesn't want to learn configuration management best practices.

The out-sourcing of work to TCS definitely hasn't helped either. For anyone who has worked with them, or similar companies, it may not come as a surprise that you suddenly find yourself interacting mostly with "Senior Engineers" or "Experts" with a complete lack of understanding of what they are doing, trying their best to keep up a facade.
Advice to Management
I think that R&D IT needs a major culture change. Management needs to recognize that consistently ignoring industry best practices is going to have consequences. I believe that Ericsson at a company right now is in a position where it will have a hard time to retain skilled engineers.

There may be an opportunity to start transformations after the migrations are done. Make sure that smaller teams can deliver clearly defined services, and that service interfaces are clearly defined.

I kind of hate to say it, but start implementing ITIL - the chapter of the ITIL book describing the problems it's supposed to solve is like reading a textbook on Ericsson.
Be the first to find this review helpful

There may be an opportunity to start transformations after the migrations are done. Make sure that smaller teams can deliver clearly defined services, and that service interfaces are clearly defined.

review_title: Disrespectful management, disorganized, toxic environment that does not value employees
pros: Benefits, Flexible schedule to work from home and have modified hours if you are one of the "favorites", Happy Hours almost weekly to ply you with alcohol to hide the depression all the staff have.
cons:
HORRIBLE culture of favoritism. This office epitomizes the 90 -10 rule. 10% of the staff or less does any of the work while the rest are allowed to show up late or not at all and do little to no work. This office needs a total makeover from staff and management. TOXIC culture that does not allow growth or upward movement. Instead of addressing problems, they bring in old staff that just continue to repeat the same way of working that no longer works. This company does not allow any work life balance if you are one of the few that are expected to work. Also, when I left the company, they withheld my last paycheck and I had to wait 3 days until the regular pay period to be paid. I was also not allowed to have an exit interview with HR.
Advice to Management
Change of management and real change of culture is needed. Stop disrespecting staff and allow for movement to other business and customer units. Have a manager that is actually in the office for the site acquisition staff and have a manager that actually cares about people not just his few friends.

review_title: Shambolic and inefficient. Poor technical capability at every level.
pros:
The work ethic is non-existent. If you want to work as little as possible, take sick leave every week and take home a fairly small pay-cheque, then Ericsson is for you.

Expectations are low. If you're not academically strong or motivated, then this won't hold you back at Ericsson.
cons:
The work ethic is non-existent. If you want to work hard, learn, improve and be recognized for your efforts, then don't even consider Ericsson.

Salary "increases" are pathetic. Despite 100% superb feedback from everyone I worked with, I received a salary increase below inflation (effectively a pay cut).

Technical competence is extremely low. The bar for entry is very low, so Ericsson is full of people with weak academic backgrounds and very low technical capability. If you value working with (and learning from) smart people, then you will be frustrated at Ericsson. This also brings the issue that if you have high technical competence, then you will not be recognized because no one really understands what you have done.

Ericsson brings big-company inefficiency to a whole new level. People are always too busy to do any work. Technical issues (that completely halt development for entire teams of developers) are a very regular occurrence. Every seemingly small task takes a ridiculous amount of time to pass through all the layers of bureaucracy. There is absolutely no collaboration between teams, so development effort is repeated over and over again. Technical documentation is always: unnecessarily long, out of date (or just incorrect), unclear, incomplete and lacking the few necessary details.
Advice to Management
Expect more from your employees. Fire the 80% that are contributing nothing (or less than nothing). Don't be so afraid to change processes that are completely failing. Have a plan. Target inefficiency. Work much harder to employ people with stronger technical competence. Use those people to increase competence among their colleagues. Throwing money at training courses doesn't work.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Rock-solid, slow growth, good benefits, global opportunities, innovative R&D focus
pros: There's always opportunity to move around in the company, even globally. Very Swedish culture, personal development and growth encouraged. Great benefits and a rock-solid pension fund in place. You can count on a long and challenging career here! Ericsson has always managed to remain relevant, mainly because of the large patent portfolio and heavy SW R&D focus, primarily in the radio HW and 5G telecom fields.
cons:
Tends to focus on near-term profits for shareholder benefit, often implemented through frequent trimming of products/services as well as restructuring (the annual re-orgs do interfere in overall productivity).

review_title: Always a fear of dread or doom
cons:
ltant in Plano, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Plenty of time off.
Cons
Always felt the overwhelming sense of doom. When I started my team was 20+ people. There were cuts after the first few months, and they kept coming regularly again and again. After a while, our learning clients gave up caring about learning because they were so worried for their job. 
The former CEO ran things into the ground by dreaming but never bringing it to realization. Thousands of people get laid off and he still gets a cushy top level job and doesn't suffer.
Advice to Management
Listen to Borje, I think he has the right idea. During the next growth spurt, don't overhire.

pros:
First of all, it really matters in which organization you end up, but if you don't like your current place, you can easily change job internally. I'll talk about my experience and what I saw around me.
- Very friendly people, good team spirit
- There is always someone who's willing to help you solving your problem
- Super flexible work time, you don't have to be there exactly 8 hours (including lunch break) as long as you get your job done (and unfortunately, even if you don't)
- Lunch break is 20 minutes long officially, but almost everyone takes an 1 hour break
- We work in Agile and Scrum, our team has free hand making technical decisions
- They are also more than happy for feedback and improvements for our tools
- Lots of opportunities to learn (internal and external courses, conferences, etc.)
- Continuous feedback
- Possibility to travel to other countries for some weeks (depending on the project)
- Relatively good location (Infopark)
- Pretty strong company laptop that you can also take home
- Once in a year big team building (~50 ppl, one night in a (usually) wellness hotel)

Overall it's a very good place as a first company.
cons:
This is literally the place where if you want to work you work, if not, you don't.
- No really, you can get away being in the office 7 hours per day (including a 1 hour lunch break and 2 * 1 hour coffee breaks)
- Some people with higher job grade do literally nothing all day, then getting promoted to scrum masters/POs/managers
- Hard to get a decent salary if you work already here
- They rather hire new people than giving actually decent salary for the talented people
- There is a 30% women target, and some are only hired or not yet fired because of this
- The canteen in the building has horrible quality and some of the staff are pretty rude
- You can only get your free 25dkg salad (or 2 fruits, and you better wash those fruits) in this canteen
- The laptop and the "docker" quality (HP) is pretty bad, for many people the USB and HDMI ports die after half year
- If you choose Windows 10 for your laptop, it's full of spywares and crappy "antivirus" software which make development slow and randomly mess up your git/python/npm environment
- The equipment in the meeting rooms don't work if you have Linux, but at least usually there is a HDMI cable

Other
The office building was obviously designed by some inexperienced Swedish person who has no idea about the summer heat (or basic physics):
- The "automatic intelligent shutters", which are between the two glass panels(!) were an epic failure:
-- They move ridiculously slowly
-- Literally half of them broke in 2 months and could be only "fixed" by replacing the entire panels
-- After this they decided to disable the automatic movement
-- They ended up adding a second line of "curtains" (because the original ones were useless)
- During super hot and humid days, water is dripping from the air conditioners from the ceiling to our desks, for what the "solution" is to turn them off
Advice to Management
Do not hire people who don't do their job, or at least fire them in the first 3 months (yes, they didn't work that even during the trial period and no one cared) or at least don't promote them FFS.
Give decent salary for talents, don't wait until they threat you with quitting.
Some more benefits would be nice like more money for small team buildings or free snacks/drinks in the office.
The laptops with Windows 10 are literally unsuitable for decent development in this shape.

Repor

pros: Good breakfast at cafeteria. And free coffee.
cons:
They don't tell u which department u will land up in. I was in A3. 

This was shared on the first day and highlighted again and again :

Office times : 9:00-17:30 - including 2 x 15min breaks (morning/afternoon) and 30mins for lunch.

If you are not in the office for any reason, you must notify your manager (XXXX XXXXX) by phone, as is company policy. Failure to do this is a disciplinary issue. Take down my number xxx xxxx xxx and save it in your phone.

See the tone - this is a disciplinary issue. I guess they forgot this is not a factory anymore.

Every engineer/colleague I spoke to said managers track what time they start day, how long they are away from desk and what time they leave. Some of them even join stand-ups. 

If u are 15min late, then u are taken into a room and told off. They even try to listen in on what u are talking to others.

Some of the engineers say they feel as if managers have camera planted or they ask other managers to keep an eye on u. Most of them said, they would quit soon because of the managers. No one will complain about this to HR or in exit interview because they feel senior management expects this from their managers. Some of the managers are notoriously famous and not in a good way.

Also, apparently it is very difficult to change teams and get into other department (unless managers wants u gone) or go against the wishes of ur manager. Unless u want to get in trouble. Managers are all powerful and have no clue about technology or people management.

Thanks goodness I was with Ericsson-Athlone only for 2 months. Even in those 2 months I was taken into a room every week. 

My advice – Stay away. If not, make sure not to join A3.
Advice to Management
Too many managers. What do you do with so many managers?

Helpful

Too many managers. What do you do with so many managers?

review_title: Good bene's but always downsizing, you feel like a number
pros:
Still decent insurance but not as good as it used to be
Salary
Good products
Great Severance packages
cons:
Benefits are constantly being dropped like stock purchase, fully paid insurance
You feel like a number, it doesn't matter how good you are you could be laid off or worse: forced to move, forced to outsource position
Outsourcing like crazy, moving entire products to the cheapest labor source to save money and then wondering why the products die
Terrible decisions that never make sense
It seems Ericsson now wants to be out of the software biz as they are selling off products, off shoring, heavy use of contractors
no opportunity to move up, training is very hard to get/find
Playing games during downsizing, forced resignations if you don't: move, if you don't stay to train your offshore replacements, take a position with a contractor, setting long or extended time windows final layoff date (hoping you will leave sooner without severance)
watching your friends and coworkers constantly being let go
dealing with new people who don't have the right skills or experience
Advice to Management
Your software and the engineers that created it are a valuable resource. Stop killing the products. 5G alone will not save the company. Start innovating again and challenge people. My product has slowed to a snails pace as everyone feels the future is bleak.

review_title: Great place to grow at the beginning!
pros:
Respectful environment.
Trying to achieve best results( great culture).
Nice building.
Refreshing laptops every three year.
Great lounge area in the building to have coffee and chat.
Gym on site.
Indoor parking (it is a big plus one for Montreal's winter)
Great people.
There is a possibility of short term assignment in other countries (e.g. Sweden, ...)
Has a cafe-teria.
Normal vacation days (around 18)
cons:
Waterfall! Even though strive is to be agile but in really every project is done in waterfall.
Management has no clue about agile development.
Not really competitive salaries.
Sometime there is no bonus at the end of the year (hopefully those dark ages of Ericsson in that past years are going to disappear).
Awful cafe-teria.
Limited budget to provide hardware resources for new employees (at least in my department).
Has a high tendency to make you lazy ( at the end of the day working in Ericsson is easy, therefor you might find yourself on the same seat for 20 years easily)
No beer!
Advice to Management
Management should open their eyes to new technologies and methodologies that are out there in the market. They always stick to what has been there already. Don't be afraid of change.

pros: Ericsson is a company that can really improve your career, full of opportunities in every area and every place in the world.
cons:
As an employee that worked in different Ericsson sites, I can say Ericsson Bellevue - WA works as a separate company, not following ericsson's values.
Work-life balance at this site is simply nonexistent. Managers treat you like you are doing something wrong if you are working from 8 to 5. And when we talk about managers, note that this place has a HUGE number of managers, almost one manager for each 2 employee and they still try to figure out why the company is facing a financial crisis.
Managers treat employees like garbage, it is normal to hear around the office managers swearing bad words with employees or even laughing at failures. It is a very toxic place. 
Note: I only experienced it at Ericsson Bellevue - WA. The company it self is great! If you can chose, run from Bellevue!
Advice to Management
Make Ericsson Bellevue to follow Ericsson's values and principles. 
And REDUCE the number of managers, you don't need all that.

Treat everyone equally or don't hire female employees .

pros:
My team was amazing. Loads to learn from my senior developer and other team members. Unfortunately, my entire team got laid off so thats that.
Good time off policy.
cons:
Management lacks overall vision. 
Reorgs happen with very high frequency.
Most of the management has no idea what the developers/engineers/ML guys actually do and its relevance or importance.
Team managers hold grudges against you if they have had bad blood with your previous managers. (happened to me when I was trying to move to a different team)
Advice to Management
Try to be an active participant in your employee's work and contribution. Take care of your employees in general. Avoid frequent layoffs and restructuring due to politics. It affects everyone.

review_title: Good place if it has less politics
pros: - Adaptable work life balance.
cons:
- No bonus 
- Very less salary hike .
- No office transportation.
- No food coupons.
- Outdated technologies 
- Office politics at its peak . 
- Managers has no technical knowledge. 
- Too much employee to manager ratio. No manager leaves company . They getting stalled here . 
- Interview process is not transparent and good enough . Even persons who don't know programming language can also get job here . 
- Too much groupism . 
- Learning curve is literally flat.
- No perks for employees.
- No one cares about design and architecture .
- If they have no resource , even they make testers as developer/lead and drive projects. Eventually this will end up as conflict between people , because of little/no technical knowledge at other side.
Advice to Management
- Reduce office politics . Sometimes its getting worst and the employees leave company only because of politics.
- Hire good talents.
- Interview process needs to be refined .
- Own employees can be paid better than consultants.

review_title: Good opportunity to learn. Great work life balance. Overall a good company
pros:
Great work life balance
Good team culture
Good place to learn new skills.
cons:
Growth is limited owing to very stratified hierarchical levels.
Hike is not that great although if one manages to travel, which is a lot more in my job profile, he/she can take home good ad hoc allowance.
Advice to Management
Ericsson India is still very much behind on adapting technologies that are currently trending in the market. We have a lot of obsolete processes that bring no value to us or Customers. Adapt to relevant processes.

Growth of an employee at every level is important. Management needs to bring in better measures to facilitate such aspects.

review_title: Large Company and all of the attendant issues
pros: Ericsson is an established global telecom leader. As such, it offers many benefits including myriad job functions, departments, and a presence in nearly every conceivable location. Opportunities to work with every nameplate technology company abound, as do options for career paths.
cons:
The downside to a company of Ericsson's size and the nature of its desire to expand from its primary function (telecom equipment manufacturer) is that it ends up trying to be all things to all partners.

Unfortunately, Ericsson is a victim of its own success. It grew quite large on its reputation as a manufacturer of excellent telecommunications equipment, and has attempted to leverage that success by expanding into all areas of the ICT space. By nature, the company is good at just a few things, but is trying to participate in literally hundreds of things (managed services, cloud infrastructure, consulting, etc.) Inevitably, this leads to disappointed customers and frustrated Ericsson employees.
Advice to Management
Management should stop making all focus on the margin, and instead turn their attention to delivering quality products and services that set the standard in the marketplace. 

Consistently attempting to drive cost out of the business by offshoring critical frontline functions while increasing overhead in disposable centralized roles is a recipe for dysfunction.

review_title: Great culture, good opportunities, uncharismatic leadership (generally)
pros: Excellent work environment. Fair and inclusive culture. Plenty of opportunities for who is willing to explore and go the extra mile. Leading influencing company worldwide on certain sectors.
cons:
Generalizing, middle-high leadership layers may not be inspiring for lack of either ability to look outside the already visible corporate-horizon or of their poor curriculum of successful accomplishments for the company, leaving the impression that the company is not that result oriented when it comes to that range of leadership levels. Culturally not used to handle with clarity difficult interpersonal situations can be a loss of leadership charisma for some. The company seems to fall behind the minimum of industry practices in certain management methods (project, line). Methods and tools used to manage topic widely used in the industry (agile, SW development phases, IT management, Project Management, reporting ...etc) seemed to need to be rediscovered every time a new player enter into the picture. While challenging the way it was always done can be good on occasions, questioning the processes and methods before giving them a try is definitely adding cost.
Advice to Management
Appoint leaders at every level communicating clearly their curriculum of accomplishments (success stories), in the same manner this is already done for top executives.
Strengthen the curiosity on how the industry is advancing in efficiency from the top, by setting the right goals and objectives. Currently, most of the method and process innovation is left to the individual enthusiast practitioner.

review_title: A big ship with flashes of creativity
pros:
Ericsson is a massive company with opportunities in every country in the world.
It allowed me to see the world and work in many different positions.
Its culture is very consistent in all those offices.
Ericsson is also the undisputed market leader in radio and that is what always funded the other company growth areas.
cons:
Ericsson has been unsuccessful in making headway on the wireline side of the business and has year after year lost more territory to players like cisco. Also their attempts to grow into datacenters and IT has been a failure.
Ericsson is also burdened by a massive internal IT organisation adding a lot of overhead to the bottom line and slowing down innovation.
Advice to Management
Truly invest in modern cloud, not home-grown datacenters.
Streamline operations around engineering efficiency, reducing IT, project and program overhead. Much more direct customer engagement by engineering.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: It's an employee friendly company with good work-life balance and a proper beneficial package. It was stable employer at least in Hungary, so you didn't have to be concerned about loosing your job. The company really supports the internal movements between different products/projects, so you can work with different domains through the years at the same company.
cons:
It wasn't really clear where we are heading as a company, and what are the plans with our product. The vision changed so quickly that caused a lot of frustration and made us feel that we are just jumping around without a real plan. Too much politics between the different sites. The internal communication about strategy, changes was really weak, that caused a lot of unnecessary tension.
Advice to Management
Value the knowledge, not the political activities, and try to communicate better internally.

review_title: Tech saavy, having great products with great specs is the only that matters. Internal reorg is taking too long.
pros: Very stable despite last 2y reorgs. Enjying now the wave of 5G technology taking off. Internal mobility is great. You can work from home as much as you like in general. Slower pace environment at HQ, can get more hectic out in the markets
cons:
Very traditional and well stablished Radio Networks business is preventing new businesses from taking off. Being in a shrinking markets there is not so much room for younger employees to grow. Most of business concentrated on not so many big customers. Decisions could be speedier. Processes come before customer or creativity more often than not.
Advice to Management
Let new businesses fly, take more risks when assessing deals and promote new generation. Prune your portfolio and starts thinking of what would be left after 5G wave passes.

review_title: Full of false promises and expect more for less
pros: Personal van use, lone-working, working in greenbelt and remote sites, start/finish times, good line management.
cons:
Shockingly bad outsourced dispatch and field support teams. Managers having to pick up pieces but nothing ever changes because its cheap.
Ageing field staff who do nothing but whinge and moan because they can't keep up with technology.
50% weekends spent working.
Very low basic wage.
Sometimes hitting 80 hours on a call out week just to get by, working late into the night.
Waiting around constantly for other teams.
Dealing with bad site provider relationships.
Too much admin.
Idiots everywhere.
Advice to Management
Where to start. Don't expect the same level of loyalty and motivation when you create a new role with nothing more than a different title, to justify paying someone less but working more? The ageing field staff are laughing at you, while the new recruits are bitter and annoyed with the level of inequality.

cons:

Managers should try to interact with people and know their strengths, background before assignment of projects.

CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Great work/life balance opportunities and freedom to control your work, as long and you get done what is expected.
Cons
- Low salaries and very difficult to get promotions if you don't change job/role within the company. Don't expect to get anywhere by staying at one position.
- Telecom is a tough industry and is going through a major crunch and transformation
Advice to Management
Which people get promoted are not always the best candidates, but friends of other managers. Getting fair promotions based on performance will keep morale up.

pros: Ericsson is a great place to grow your career. They are working on cutting edge technology, have offices all over the world, and employ incredibly talented and passionate people who are great to work with. They move very fast, which can be tough for some, but those who are willing to move quickly can grow and build their skills in an accellerated and meaningful way.
cons:
Ericsson has unfortunately gone through some tough times in recent years, which has impacted the moral in some offices more than others. However, I think they are coming out of it just as strong as they were before.

5. onsite opportunity
6. overall care of the employee even if he/she is in onsite
7. good hr support and transparency 
8. conducive office environment and cleanliness
cons:
1. salary increment is less
2. onsite opportunity has become less and even if present taking release from current project / domain is a challenge
3. work/ project in latest technology is decreasing.
4. work is not always properly appreciated
Advice to Management
create scope of good work and onsite opportunities. manager feedback programs should be started.

pros: I worked with people from all over the world which was a wonderfully enriching experience. The people I worked with were overachievers who valued the importance of a job well done. Advancement in Ericsson was attainable with initiative and drive.
cons:
Work/life balance was not possible. A 40-hour workweek was for the lower performers. I believe that the offices in other countries might have had better balance, but in the US the expectation was to work long days and weekends.
Advice to Management
Consult the people who actually do the work before making promises to customers. The lowest bid is not the wisest decision. Remember that your employees are humans who not only need, but deserve to have a life outside of Ericsson.

pros:
I have been working at Ericsson full-time (Less than a year)

Ericsson provides a service to telecom company like Vodafone, Airtel etc and also provides the telecommunication and networking devices to the telecom company. My role as a Network Administrator and I learnt new things every day from configuring the network devices to detect the problem in the network devices. So if your dream is to become a network engineer or you love the Networking then this place is totally for you because you learnt a lot and after 3 or 4-year of experience in the company then the company send you the foreign country.
So, its great place to work.
cons:
Sometimes work pressure creates a headache and supposes if you master in any network or telecommunication devices then the full staff totally dependent on you and also the manager. And suppose if the device malfunctioning in midnight then manager call to you and gives the instruction to arrive the office as soon as possible to resolve the issue.
Advice to Management
Nothing to say for the management all staff member are good and always help to fresher.

review_title: It's a company where you can work and get paid, that's all!
pros:
- Still leading the telecommunication industry with many large telecom companies as its customer across the world.
- Leading the 5G revolution.
- Adapting to the change in the software and technology industry at large.
- Many smart engineers to work with.
- Lots of good perks and good work-life balance.
cons:
- Struggling to be agile in the fast-changing hardware and software industry. Dealing with the similar problems faced by big companies (although many companies have managed to change faster than Ericsson) like bureaucracy, politics, too many decision-makers, organization-wide policies (one-size-fits-all policies across geographies).
- Archaic processes and tools being used across the organization making teams and engineers drag their feet to get projects done.
- Perks not competent enough to hire good talent (especially in Bay Area).
Advice to Management
- Nothing because there is too much to say which can't fit in here.

review_title: Used to be great , But no more !!!
pros: Benefits, Work - Life Balance, Nice building, Good 401k
cons:
Lots of middle management, So that adds to non-billable resources overhead. There are lot of Directors, Project Managers, Program Managers, Technical Managers, Solutions Architect I, II,III,IV (With very less technical competence, kiss goodbye to functional competence)... Unfortunately less engineer who perform the actual work. For the past 3-4 years, the trend is after any acquisition ,new group (with their own family and friends) comes over with hefty package and takes over looming uncertainty. Lot of departments are bleeding, with unreasonable wish list & promises to customer. (Reason refer above)
Advice to Management
Cut down the non billable resource, Get rid of thick middle management, Hire Engineers, Promote only engineers with sound, technical & functional knowledge as Solutions Architect or higher up.

pros: The people at Ericsson Television were fantastic, whether it was just a friendly chat or in a meeting, they were always willing to help and very friendly. These people were people you could go for a beer with anytime and have a great time. The working environment was very engaging and friendly, with a weekly football kick around happening weekly. For those who didn't like playing, there was always the fantasy which encouraged everyone to get together and talk about something they enjoy! The work I completed there was in depth and of great importance. The reports I produced went around the world and being given that responsibility was quite rewarding! There were opportunities to get into other parts of finance and learn more about processes which was great! The cooked breakfast was fantastic and reasonably priced.
cons:
During my time there, one downside was that within finance, there wasn't as much to do. You'd do the monthly and weekly reports but apart from that, there wasn't much to do.
Advice to Management
Keep employing very friendly people. It makes the experience really enjoyable being with people who are very friendly and easy to get on with.

review_title: Work life Balance and Good People to Work with
pros:
1. You will have knowledgeable people around who are great to work with.
2. Work life balance.
3. If you have the requires skill and will to grow there is no stopping.
4. When I was working with Ericsson, I traveled almost every country and everyone I knew got opportunity to travel international minimum 2-3 times.

cons:
1. Salary is less as compared to market but travel incentives might cover it up.

3. Could do more to ensure people are not doing monotonous jobs.
Advice to Management
Present clear picture to the employees rather than beating around the bush at times. Everyone understand how things are with Telecom currently so better you keep them in confidence and encourage them to come up and share idea to ensure the industry sustain this tide and sail to success.

Line Manger saves his favorite team member but other engineers who are travelling for work cannot be with line manager and therefore cant be their favorite. cons:
ltant in Plano, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Not many right now. They are good with their medical benefits and their 401 K employer contribution
Cons
THe business itself is not going anywhere. As a two decade veteran of the High tech Industry with over 12 years in the video business, E/// does not have the DNA to be a video business. It is a set of telco geeks who are trying their hand at the video busienss in a completely incoherent fashion. E/// went on a shopping spree to buy their way into the video marketplace in 2014-1016 but they never integrated the pieces into one coherent product offering. The Video hierarchy is headed at the top 4 layers with telco people with precious little understanding of the video business and neither the contacts in the video business. So in my view the long term success of the Video business is very unlikely.

pros:
1. A good legacy product, that impacts worldwide.
2. Has a potential to do great things
3. Good company if you are into telecom space
4. Work life balance is sometimes okay, depends on work.
5. Good place to learn, and acquire skills.
cons:
1. Awful management, strategy changes every 6 months.
2. No vision for future of the company. It is right now in a state where it seems to not have much capital to invest in something new. All of the investment made in previous years, did not pay back the expected return. All bets are given to 5G with fingers crossed and eyes shut!
3. Decision are made, with no risk analysis of what could go wrong.
4. Decisions are made from Sweden, and Ottawa being a remote site does NOT have a 'say' to change those decisions.
5. Too much politics within the management and sometimes within employees.
6. Very few of the managers are complete awful! They should not be given that position at all . All they need is a "Yes man!" mindset of people.
7. Hiring mechanism is broken. As long as you can type, and are human, you are "in".
8. Within Canada, Ericsson has lost the reputation to get new grads and experienced engineers from reputable universities. It has become more of a "training ground" where you learn and leave as soon as possible. 
9. No stock options.
10. Free parking is given as a perk !
11. Company is doing too much of cost cutting, for that, they are loosing some of the basics in keeping this ship sane.
12. Raise are given based on "visibility" among the management.
13. Morale of employee is all time low.
14. Age difference between new grads and experienced is getting big. Time to say hello to your grandparents.
15. Whole company is slow. Not agile.
16. Telecom space is becoming a "Dinosaur technology", so for new grads it does not interest much. 
17. Company is not evolving as fast as the market around. 
18. Not a market leader in telecom space anymore.
17. There is a growing population of seniors who are near to retirement, that were hired at the time of Nortel, and the management is not doing anything to train to replace them.
18. A small number of the managers do not know the difficulties of developers. They would just say things, literally anything to sound 'technical', use you for their selfish agenda, not because it is helping the company but because each manager has to show something, that they are doing "something". A , classic out of the book, good-old narcissist.
Advice to Management
Listen to your employees! You have received feedback in many forms (either through company wide survey, individual feedback and/or through people leaving the company). Don't just pass on the problem like a hot potato, pay heed to the raised issues and not just mark them as fixed only for "book-keeping" purposes, and to show to the upper management "how good you are in solving problems"!

cons:
ltant in Plano, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
When you are there they have decent benefits. (Or used to) Decent work life balance - at least in the groups I was in. Being South Asian is a big plus to working there. The new CEO seems to be turning things around, but E will never be the 800 lb gorilla again.
Cons
From the time I started in 2012 - it was a continual stream of downsizing in North America. Loss loss loss. Ericsson lost it's market leadership due to hubris and bad decisions. The morale was extremely low when I left. Stay a year or two then start looking for another job before they cut you. Don't get complacent.
Advice to Management
Focus on what made /// great in the beginning. It was quality - not cheap offshore labor. Focus on the core competency.

review_title: Supply Chain Design and Control VI
pros: Above average benefits, fast changing environment, cutting edge technology, very human-centric ethical corporation. Swedish norms are more employee friendly and value the individual. Mostly a very nurturing, supportive, and collaborative workplace.
cons:
Like most large corporations, Ericsson was usually slow to make needed changes and usually 'over-reacted' because of their own delays. In many cases, the reorgs left many employees with managers that did not understand how the business was run.
Advice to Management
Listen to any hints or allegations of nepotism among management. Employees that add real value and merit that suffer under these unqualified managers will find somewhere else to go should the occasion arise. Usually people don't leave good companies, but they will leave incompetent and unqualified managers. Hopefully Ericsson can thrive once again if 5G truly flourishes to 20-30 Billion connected devices but, in the meantime, there will be some rough patches through this decade and beyond. Therefore, I would be hard pressed to recommend this company to a friend.

Business ethics (for example they tell you to not put Junior in front of your role in your email footer, because clients don't like to know that they are talking to inexperienced employees).

Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Good opportunity to learn new staff, growing your knowledge in new technology.

Advice to Management
More carefully evaluate available resources before making a decision to cut the cost over the workforce. Make management more transparent, eliminate additional multi-layers mid management structure.

pros: Strong in radio hardware and network deployment. Impressive heritage. Good reputation.
cons:
Weak in virtually every other area. Software and associated services and delivery organizations perform poorly. Sales team is singularly focused on hardware (radio and core network) deals. The Swedish culture of consensus permeates most business operations, slowing things down unnecessarily. Lack of commitment and R&D funding towards smaller revenue areas limits their ability to execute and stay competitive.
Advice to Management
Stop trying to replicate your success in the radio business elsewhere using the same principals. Stick to the strategy you define, trust the team you have in place, and give them the enabled sales team and R&D funding to make it successful.
