review_title: A company that was absolutely fantastic
pros:
Working in a truly Global, fast paced environment. Lots of challenges to work with, and at least earlier - lots of empowerment to take own initiative individually or with informal teams.
Working at the forefront of the evolution of communication industry.
An organization that can manage absolutely wonderful things on small and large scale.
cons:
The following are issues that popped up the last 2-3 years. Before that Ericsson was definitely a place where you could happily work your entire working life with a constant flow of engaging challenges.

But lately many parts of the company went into "panic mode". The Change of CEO (to Borje Ekholm) lead to a completely new top layer of managers, which is understandable. But they then continued to swap out almost all manager below them etc, leaving the company with a large number of managers started to drive changes that were not in line with what the CEO was communicating. I witnessed/suffered with senior managers that kept changing directives on weekly basis for an entire year, and stopped listening to input. But that was only one part of Ericsson. Big reductions in staff were done in parts of the business that was extremely profitable (instead of concentrating reductions or selling off parts where the problems actually were).
Advice to Management
You need to look the people sitting between the CEO and the department managers. The great vision of the CEO is currently lost as it ends up in initiatives further down in the organization, and it is in my mind hurting the company a lot.

review_title: Sinking fast and Swedes get all the lifeboats
pros: Innovative company; never stands still. I always was presented with new challenges. Friendly, but demanding atmosphere. Pay and benefits are good, and they honor their commitments. Trips to Sweden are fun.
cons:
Led by Swedish culture. Nice people, but things move slowly. Swedish employees take the whole summer off, while US employees keep working hard. Then when they need to downsize, Sweden is retained (they can't lay them off), and all the layoffs happen in the US. Ericsson does not seem to appreciate the hard-working Americans as much as if you are born in Sweden.
Advice to Management
Focus on your most productive employees and work areas. Reward hard work, not culture.

pros:
1) Extensive repository of learning and reference materials which are easily accessible online.
2) Strong learning culture and learning opportunities.
3) Advocates and encourages respect and inclusiveness - opinions are heard. Global employee survey performed annually to understand areas for improvement. 
4) Advocates and encourages openness - top management does not hide behind closed doors. 
5) Opportunities for overseas postings (new experiences).
cons:
1) Consensus approach tends to slow decision making.
2) Battling with market share - shrinking career opportunities and increasingly higher workload.
3) Inconsistency of behavior - opening and inclusiveness varies between managers .
4) Long hours, typically in customer facing positions.

pros:
Never start your career with this company. 
Freshers are being treated as slaves.
There are no pros to write about this company.
Absolutely nothing.
cons:
Every single thing about the company. 
Very bad choice to start a career with this company. 
I’m writing this to know all the college pass outs out there to make a wise decision by not joining this company.
The work sucks. It is equivalent to a call centre job. 
Managers and the management sucks. You will be mentally harassed. And there are senior people who support such a misconduct.
There is no difference between the work assigned to you and the other team members( senior engineer , specialist). The only difference is GETs and the engineers will be paid less. 
Most important point to note, you will not be given any hike during the 1st appraisal and this applies to certain departments only and also there is no variable pay.
You will be paid below the industry standards.
All the above applies to the freshers. 
For Freshers, who are reading this review consider this as my personal suggestion - "Never join this company in case you have been recruited on campus”.
No hygiene is maintained in the canteen.
Work will be done by the GETs and the engineers and all the credits are taken by the managers.
Managers are very inefficient and Egoistic. They get the work done by blackmailing the employees.
And will preach about workplace ethics.
Advice to Management
This company doesn’t deserve even 1 star rating but couldn’t rate it low.
Given an option I would rate it “0”.
What is the point in advising when no actions will be taken, just a waste of time and words.
For people who are working at Ericsson, Quest for easy is of no use. Things which are broken will remain broken at this place or it might worsen. I don’t find any positive vibe for improvements at this place.

review_title: Company with great history experiencing rough times
pros:
- Corporate culture based on Swedish values - mutual respect and diversity
- Worldwide presence that opens good career perspectives
- Great and glorious history on telecom market
- Decent compensation package (payroll, insurances, lunches, etc.) in general
- Nice and comfortable offices around the world
cons:
- Enormous amount of bureaucracy and redundant processes with no value 
- Rapid decline in market share and sales as the company looses to its competitors
- Inability to transform from pure Telecom into the ICT company
- Salaries inequality - some people are seriously overpaid or underpaid
Advice to Management
- Develop a corporate culture of big actions instead of talking big
- Invest in attracting and keeping best employees and not hesitate to get rid of under-qualified ones
- Make an emphasis on improving the product quality
- Simplify processes as they kill employees' enthusiasm to work

review_title: Lowest salaries, excessive unpaid work, sweatshop layout
pros: Co-workers are nice, but most frustrated and looking to leave so the moral isn't good. Ericsson
cons:
- lowest salary (also does not negotiate/budge on lowball offers. ie. take it or leave it attitude).
- No benefits. Other companies pay health (US), free drinks, free food, pension contributions, given RSUs/stock. Ericsson has none of that!
- Ericsson advertises "free parking" as a perk because they don't have any perks. (parking is free everywhere around Ericsson Ottawa so it's not a perk).
- Lots of unpaid work after hours & weekends. Don't expect appreciation or compensation. They just don't care.
- Agile meetings daily to micro-manage you.
- Terrible HR. Ericsson HR is your enemy and only there to force you to take their lowball offer and 
- Ericsson HR in Texas makes changes/decisions to Ericsson elsewhere (Ottawa for example) like turning Ottawa into a sweatshop layout and dynamic seating. Turns out HR doesn't have a clue how engineering work (go figure) and now people are constantly sick due to the sweatshop layout which seats 6 people 2 feet from each other with no divisions. Noise is a problem. People wear headphones and earplugs to drown out the noise. Dynamic seating was abandoned. HR still won't admit they screwed up big time.
- People leave. Company is bleeding.
- Huawei has surpassed Ericsson and Ericsson is on track for bankruptcy.
- Virtual teams means you are 50% in one team under one virtual manager and 70% under manager. 50%+70% adds up to more than 100%. Smart aren't they!!
- Some workers are getting away with doing nothing. A kid in my team came in a 11am and left a 2-3pm each day. Others commit a line of code once every couple of weeks, but they first submit garbage work and the reviewers have to tell them out to fix it so that it doesn't crash the products. So essentially they contribute nothing.
- Directors are pretty useless.
- Excessive meetings (Some people like this because they use meetings as excuses to never do any work).
- Ericsson as most companies in the Kanata Tech park only exist due to cheap obedient foreign labor. 
- Ericsson and other Kanata tech park companies produce more dual citizenships than actual product. (ie. Citizenship Manufacturing is the primary product).
- Canada needs to cut back on immigration.
- Canada needs to cut back on mass graduation. At this time there are not enough blue collar workers as witnessed by the rise of blue collar workers salaries well above normal and the stagnation of Engineering salaries (decline if inflation is factored in).
Advice to Management
- Fire hr and let Engineering Managers make decisions.
- Pay wages that will help retain talent instead of always trying to hire foreigners and beg to gov of Canada to flood the STEM marker to create an artificial employer's market and suppress wages. (in other words, let the market set wages instead of politicians, execs, hr trying to decide what they think they should pay you - the envy, jealousy that hr and politicians have toward STEM is very apparent and shows in the decision to artifically set market rates while giving over fields, like the pulbic sector workers, doctors, etc raises)
- If Ericsson is unable to pay, they can always look for less qualified workers such as high school grads, 2 year college grads. That all Ericsson seems to want to pay for (can afford).
- Management needs to gain an appreciation for good work/talent and try to attract it. Low-balling doesn't work. The difference between Silicone Valey and crap-ttawa is this understanding in the Valey that Engineers are your future and good Engineers are worth every penny you invest. Crap-ttawa only wants to slave-drive low paid Engineers into producing for a couple years at low rates until the Engineer realizes its not worth it. No wonder crap-ttawa never poduced anything, despite having floods of bright, ultra-talented Engineers that Silicone Valey is stealing away constantly.

ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Well stated corporate culture and values 
Great hard working employees at the execution level
Generally very collaborative
Cons
No defined strategy or integration / alignment between consulting and solutions, with limited understanding of the difference between Management consulting, consultative selling, and systems integration consulting.
Stated values are poorly executed by middle management, to the extent of being almost meaningless (state one thing, abandon in day to day actions) 
Lacks dynamism and innovation 
Continued issues with poor product functions and capabilities 
Services business is purely cost recovery utilization driven
Pays lip service to professional and career development
Managerial and leadership capabilities of employees are not identified or developed well 
Continued organization design changes, and turnover of middle managers contributes to poor execution, and lack of commitment
Advice to Management
Listen and act upon the annual Dialogue survey of employees - the challenges faced by the business now were clearly identified at the "grass roots" level 2 years ago.
Create an agile and adaptable end to end collaborative organization design, which is more attuned to the needs of customers, not vertical silos of dysfunctional technical go to market delivery units

pros:
Nice office space
Friendly atmosphere
cons:
Incompetent, technologically illiterate management.
A culture of avoiding responsibility.
Outdated tech stack.
Complete lack of interest in career planning & career development of employees - people are reshuffled between unrelated roles at will regardless of their current skillset, interests and wishes - you could be a manager one day, and a developer the next with little to no say in the matter.
Lack of transparency in career progression & pay.
Meaningless yearly performance review process - irrelevant copy/pasted goals; scores that don't line up with the actual written feedback; scores have minimal impact on compensation.
Lack of communication with management - some employees only get 1 or 2 chances for a face-to-face session with their direct manager a year.
Excessive amount of red tape - over-reliance on meetings without clear goals and purpose; everything is a word document or a powerpoint presentation (often both); every team is a Scrum team, regardless of how well it fits.
Low standard of internal developer documentation - work with internal tools and libraries is an exercise in frustration.
Siloing - teams, departments and offices are very isolated from each other.
High employee turnover.

ant change, mediocre management
29 Jan 2018 - Customer Facing in Stockholm, Stockholm, Stockholm
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Low to no pressure. Excellent customer base. Truly global organisation. Some excellent people work here who know everything there is to know about their particular field/product.
Cons
Hugely political, almost comedically so. Far, far too many managers. huge amounts of overlap between roles and departments which leads to no responsibility and zero accountability. Weak culture with strategy taken as 'guidance' rather than gospel. Leadership seems incredibly arrogant, possibly due to the fat that most people have been here well over 10 years. Needs to shift FAST to an XaaS model, but no real signs of that happening.
Advice to Management
Make your strategy compulsory. Slimline your sales operations - 4 people doing the same thing is simply poor. Learn from your competitors/partners - their experience could teach you a LOT. And reinstate the share scheme - how can employees really be vested in the companies future if we can't share in it financially?

review_title: Things could be better, maybe 5G will help?
cons:
ruction Manager in San Francisco, CA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Benefits and salary are good. Some good people too.
Cons
Management is pretty clueless and they don't have the guts or power to fix the situation we are in right now. Despite having a lot of work right now, we can't hire additional staff. In fact, quite the opposite is happening. We are working long hours and losing people (because maybe the grass is greener on the other side of the fence, or because management refuses to keep good people). Fear of layoffs is pretty high.
Advice to Management
We have a lot of good people. Instead of just laying them off left and right, maybe look at areas of the business that are doing well (I know there isn't a lot in that category) and, instead of shoving people out the door, offer them the opportunity to move into an area they may be able to help in and perhaps even enjoy.

Looking at mainstream information security doctrine, risk is a basic metric in security management. Risk assessments are performed based on the formula
Risk = Threats * Vulnerabilities * Impact
cons:

it is very important to focus on proactive and reactive procedure

review_title: Not a good place for building software
pros:
Perhaps at the very top they have good ideas, and perhaps at the very bottom they are capable of execution. 
Generally good people.
cons:
E/// was (is?) incapable of adopting a software-development mindset. They are very hidebound, with many layers of bureaucracy in which helping one another to achieve larger goals isn't emphasized. They don't have a culture that encourages taking risks, or iterating and introspecting through failure to learn and change and grow, which is a necessary part of the software development methodology.
Advice to Management
The vast middle is a bloated bureaucracy filled with rot and intransigence. It's not for nothing that Ericsson is known in Sweden as "The largest adult daycare in the country". If E/// wants to play in the software space that needs to be fixed, to connect the top with the implementors and empower teams to make Ericsson successful again. Right now the company is organized in a way that kills innovation.

review_title: A once great company off in a different direction
pros: Global perspective, great talent and solid products. Pro/Con Benefits were amazing prior to 2018 but now industry standard.
cons:
Questionable choices in acquisitions are haunting the company and management is still trying to recover. Necessary layoffs went way to far (by 50%). Well placed Managers of poor performing or dismantled groups reassigned and promoted to business areas they didn't understand or manage well. Managers are ineffective and fearful of current group head. Revolving door management, good ones leave or fired, bad one stay. Products they believe are the future are dragging the company down while the core money makers are left to languish without proper support. Over-complicated business and customer management systems.
Advice to Management
Not being a CEO or trained for that level of management it would be difficult to make a recommendation. I can say that the Former CEO really knew how to rally investors and customers, this one not so much. The CEO needs of this company require a strong balance sales and tech to promote the company and its products. 
Was the former CEO perfect...no but he was a man of the people and knew how to sell. As a numbers man you know the bottom line and that is important however more often than not the bottom line is easier to manage when you are actually selling products. 
Another example of how Management can take a great company with a positive future to something not that great.

review_title: Highly Unpredictable, worst management and absolutely no job security
pros: It's a big organization and still have a brand image.
cons:
Where do I start with... 
They treat their resources as something they can just use and dump. 
Once your project gets over, their is high probability that you'll be out of office maybe very next day, despite being fresher or whatsoever. They don't consider what are you going to do with 6 months or 1 year of Experience. 
Although they pay you for 3 months, but it's like treating somebody like a cattle and finally giving them few bucks in the name of Ericsson goodwill. 
They blindly just lay off employees, even if they're hired just couple of months back as freshers, who rejected the offers of IT giant like infy/cogni to join this "not so promising" organization EGIL. 
If you're a fresher, I highly recommend you to opt for anything but EGIL. 
Although EIL is doing alright, job security is still intact.
Advice to Management
Don't treat your resources as cattles, treat us as human too. 
You were once at our place.

Stop arbitrarily laying off people in the US since it is easy and lay off people (when need) based on merit

review_title: Strong work culture & process oriented "Global Telco" global product leader
pros:
Ericsson is an outstanding "product driven" global conglomerate owning strong value creation and work culture since past 141 years. Ericsson's contribution to the global telecom industry has a clear reflection of Swedish culture of driving innovation and promoting new ways of work.
My experience in Ericsson is tremendous, starting from highly regarded global leadership driving the organization to product development approach and employee friendly environment. 
There are shift of technologies in the industry which is very much obvious (If you believe in Kondratiev wave theory) and currently there is a global "turmoil situation" in ICT & Telco companies. I am sure, Ericsson's "thrust" and "leadership" for 5G launching will change the "dimension" of global IT market and will help stabilizing the market as "pioneer" once again.
cons:
Past year/s there are global transformation of technology shift which also effect the Ericsson Delivery model and it is common for all industries today, can't agree that as a "con" as such. 5G official global launching and "pre-integration" will reinstate Ericsson a pioneer and global leader in the emerging market.
Advice to Management
1) Relevant resource
2) Less Manager
3) More automation
4) Train up existing resources on emerging technologies
5) More security centric solutions
6) Transformation of OSS/ BSS services in virtualized box/ Cloud (containerised) using Microservices Architecture and pre-integration drive.

pros: Good company to work for. Very proud of their heritage and ways in which they've brought communications and technology to the masses. Now they need to change as their dominant position has been lost to Chinese competitors.
cons:
Obsession with improving margins has led to large scale restructuring. This has meant the bottom tier of the company has been slashed with work being off-shored. Middle management tiers have moved but largely remain. Career development is either non-existent, or sideways or downwards.
Advice to Management
Listen more to the customer, and staff. The operators want better efficiency and ROI, Ericsson tries to sell more features, and 'science-fiction' solutions. Staff want to feel secure, and that there is a future ahead. Too much 'work creation' is happening as employees are not challenged and supported to move up.

pros: Nice colleagues. medical insurance is okay.
cons:
Leadership is running on panic fumes. Strategy is unrealistic and we would keep getting ceo messages that we have to sell and push, while we were not given any guarantee of our jobs or a solid reason why we should still believe in Ericsson. Moreover, due to financial constraints they're firing people and dumping all remaining work onto exisiting staff with no compensation other than be happy you have a job attitude, so there is a lot of burn out and senior leadership does not give a damn about employee well being. Also they keep the consultants and contingency workers, while they lay off perm employees. Anyone who does not have a Swede backing them or pushing for them will lose ground fast.
Advice to Management
Cut consultants, keep perm employees and retrain where necessary and don't do that only in SWEDEN/HQ. Even if you lay off 25K perm employees by Dec 31th you still won't make the numbers enough to impress stock holders or the market, as the sales are still flat. So, best focus on the perm employees, give them a reason to want to stay. otherwise even those who stay will not be loyal or care about this organization. Worse yet, they'll go work for your competitors and they'll make it their mission to ensure that your competitors succeed and pass you more than they already have.

pros: I wish so badly I could enumerate some
cons:
I feel I lost 6 and half years of my life working for this company. Almost no possibility to develop my professional skills. Big work load. Bad company culture. Lots of futile stress. Bad work/life balance. Bad gain/loss ratio. Big chances to burn out in a few years. Besides, management is burried into vanity: after more than 20 years of working only or mostly for this company they think they are the best because they have no base of comparison. I would not recommend this company even to my enemies. I never wish to come back.
Advice to Management
Take care of your employee. Sooner or later people will find out about the company culture. It is easy to fire people and hire 4 students instead of one employee for the same amount of money, then make them compete and fire half of them in 6 months, but sooner or later noone will want to work for your company because they will find out what really lays behind the promises.

pros: W/L balance - but still lot depends on manager. If manager is good, nothing is a problem, but salary hike will be a problem anyways for some people.
cons:
1. Everyone talks of innovation but actually there is no innovation seen. Big ideas are not entertained. GETs are expected to learn everything on their own and become experts by reading complex documentation.
2. HR is such a show-off. There are no learning taken from exit interviews.
 They are least concerned about your career growth. 
3. For promotion, you need to clear unimaginable certifications just to qualify for promotions. After that, if your manager wants , he will promote you, otherwise not.
4. Employees are forced to take Ericsson Technical Certification - which has no market value. It's usual for people to take shortcut to clear such exams when it is forced upon them. Then you play good cop by saying we have tightened certification policies.
Advice to Management
1. Groom GETs. They need direction. They join Ericsson as a dream company but leave because of poor direction. Then you say Ericsson needs fresh talent.
2. Recognize hard/smart workers. The one who works till 1AM doesn't get any substantial benefit that someone who doesn't work much even in office hours.
3. Give reasons to employees to clear tech. certifications. Not one person is happy to study for these certifications.

review_title: Was a great place to work
cons:
ltant in Denver, CO
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
* Great opportunity to meet with customers and service providers around the world
* It's Ericsson, a trusted partner for service providers
* Flexible Working environment, not a problem being a remote employee
* Great benefit package
Cons
* The restructuring is not going well, they are cutting key areas within the company
* They are pulling back from manufacturing
* Extreme pressure by the stockholders to turn the corner and become profitable again
* More deep employee reductions looming in the future
Advice to Management
Reach out to your employees. In times of restructuring, the employees are your most valuable assets and during times of uncertainty, those that can find other jobs, will so talk to them and be honest with them about their future and where they fit into the big picture.

review_title: One of the best places to work if you can manage to stay in it
pros:
Very well structured and organized.
Ericsson is very professional when it comes to delivering fast track projects
They can simply do what others cannot
Very huge number of employees(almost 120,000), which gives you a great chance to meet and get introduced to different people from different cultures/countries.
cons:
Many employees/managers are giving a bad image about it with their bad behavior.
Some nationalities make lobbies in some country offices, which makes it very hard for you to work with them as they prefer to get their own people.
Ericsson does layoffs every now and then, and that's a very serious issue when it comes to career stability.
Ericsson changes its organizational structure very frequently, and that's really bad as every year you end up with a new manager who knows nothing about you, and hence you have to start to prove yourself again and again.
Advice to Management
I hope that you could really make it with the new organization and new changes, coz Ericsson is a treasure to the telecom industry and it has to stay in the market. 
I am proud that I worked in Ericsson for 13 years, and I hope to work in it again 1 day.
Good luck and God be with you

review_title: Negative experience as QA Engineer/TW in Mississauga ON Canada
pros:
Benefits are good but paid for monthly 18 days vacation to start
Salary is good
Location is easy to get to by car, free parking
Ehealth program is supported by many employees
Open concept office space and hydraulic standing desks for all
Some flexibility and work from home, depending on which team you are on Developers work all hours and are typically on site from 10am to 4pm
Free coffee and tea
cons:
I was recruited and misled about a number of things. The recruiter told me benefits were free and refused to provide details of coverage. Found out during onboarding that was not the case. The role described during the interview to lure me away from my fulltime job was not the role I ended up doing. No explanation was ever provided. Paid meal breaks were not provided for an 8 hr work day. Product training was non-existent, my questions were never addressed. There seemed to be a general lack of knowledge on the manager's part. I was isolated from project and product management, making my tasks difficult.
Culture seems odd, people reported having personal items disappear from their desks, this was ignored by management. Management has a habit of gossiping about employees in a negative manner.
Too many other problems to list here, if you accept a role ensure the offer is reviewed by a lawyer as many clauses violate the ESA in Ontario. Was warned by my lawyer to turn the offer down but I had high hopes for a once greatly admired brand.
Advice to Management
A revolving door of employees for a certain role indicates the problem is with the manager. If the entire team gives a manager poor reviews....why not listen?

review_title: Good work life balance but poor management
pros:
Good work life balance.
Flexible working hours.
Work from home and leaves are usually approved easily.
cons:
Poor management with lots of politics involved in the decision making process.
Non-technical managers try to micro-manage technical tasks and end up creating irrelevant, flawed and impractical processes at times.
Lots of employee benefits are being taken away in light of the consistently poor performance of the organization.
Huge pay disparity among employees working with same work experience and same Job Level leads to frustration at times.
Weak HR makes it difficult to seek resolution to issues/disputes involving higher management.
Advice to Management
Consider employees as an asset to the organization. Focus on employee satisfaction and employee retention as well.
Hiring non-technical managers just because they demand less salary compensation has been the bane for R&D department.

cons:
Salary is growing adrift from market norms and increases year on year are currently small and tracking below real inflation. They try to justify this based on location and work life balance but it doesn't hold that well as cost of living rising here steeply. Management have a tendency to revert strongly to command and control under pressure. Bit cliquey and appointments to roles not always that transparent.
Advice to Management
Try to address root causes instead of reverting to command and control. Take a chance on people who think differently to you. More of the same will get you just that and company needs to grow right now.

review_title: Excellent benefits, floundering strategy and entrenched executives
pros: Very generous benefits, strong global presence/name recognition, good compensation
cons:
Company strategy does not align with rapidly changing ICT industry trends, organization is failing to adapt, appears to believe it can tell customers what they need/should buy. Executive leadership rotates through from job to job, very little infusion of new executive talent from within the organization or from outside.
Advice to Management
Identify your two or three key strengths and how you'll leverage them to develop and maintain competitive advantage, then drop the current "all things to everyone" vision and focus on those strengths, aggressively cutting unproductive lines of business. Exit unproductive executives from the organization aggressively, replace with strong talent from the lower levels of the organization and bring in leaders from other industries to build a winning team.

pros: Great place to be for cutting edge wireless products and services. I feel like I make an impact to the industry and people's lives.
cons:
Incredibly political atmosphere. Continual management, organization and process change. Too much offshoring which leads to job security concern.
Advice to Management
Offshoring is as costly as utilizing onshore resources due to time zone differences and multiple review cycles to get error free work. Quit changing the org charts every year. Streamline your internal divisions to avoid duplication of effort. Executive management sits too far away from the work. Most executive mgr's do not understand how to deliver a project. Stop taking away or reducing benefits (stock match/insurance).

CEO Approval

review_title: Good place to gain experience, poor career opportunities
pros:
Cutting edge technology
Good work-life balance
The new CEO seems full of good ideas to turn things around with innovative ideas but will struggle if he keeps the current dead weight in management.
cons:
Opportunities to further your career by promotions or moving into other fields (ie engineering into project management) are difficult to do and often takes years to occur. 
Pay rises are terrible, often less than 1.5% per annum. 
The hard to come by promotions means that often staff are far more experienced and contribute much more to projects than they should be for their level and pay-grade, resulting in an unconscionable win for a stingy business.
Too much management, I worked there 10yrs+ and all I saw management do was regurgitate what higher management told them and rarely add value to the business.
Advice to Management
Cut management to the bone, promote and adequately pay staff commensurate with skills and experience.
Streamline the business and get rid of useless internal/HR related activities which just result in just extra expense and holds Ericsson back from being competitive in the market

review_title: A Once-Great Company Slowly Being Killed By Internal Bureaucracy
pros: Excellent benefits: medical, dental, vision, employee and spouse insurance, matched 401(k). Challenging work. Diverse workforce from all around the world. Good work/life balance. Great internal culture. Excellent opportunities to travel internationally.
cons:
A almost unbreakable "silo" mentality that prevents teams from coordinating and collaborating effectively. Everyone is fighting to protect their little kingdoms. Management is focused exclusively in cutting costs, ignoring the trends of the telecom and high-tech industries. Management is obsessed with following processes to the detriment of actually accomplishing goals. Strong lack of willingness to take responsibility and accountability; everyone is looking for someone else to blame instead of trying to resolve issues.
Advice to Management
Stop outsourcing everything to India. Fire everyone from the director level up and bring in new people. Stop trying to be a player in fields that Ericsson has no experience or knowledge in. Focus less on cost-cutting and more on cutting-edge research and development.

review_title: Constant bad news and constant layoffs for the last 10 years. Little chance to grow. Self-promotion is a must.
cons:
ant bad news and constant layoffs for the last 10 years. Little chance to grow. Self-promotion is a must.
20 Aug 2017 - Senior Software Engineer in Helsinki, Southern Finland, Southern Finland
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
It is a job that pays money. You can try to do different things in different roles and you can learn new things. People are polite and nice. Coworkers are excellent professionals.
Cons
- it used to have good work-life balance.
- health plan is good on paper not in practice.
- competition with Huawei paradoxically seems to drive permanent engineer's salaries down (?)
- developers need to hone their skills but there is no training in place and no projects.
- salary is not competitive and they won't try to match it, as you grow older you might be left out so watch out.
- meetings.
- food is not good.
- too much focus on "gender", that has alienated merit-driven people (women too).
- high pressure in projects with poor prospects.
- employees are generally demoralized and looking for alternatives.
- no career path on R&D, hard to switch within as there is no room upwards.
- few very good developers left, now the learning curve for the rest of us is much steeper.
Advice to Management
Developers have no career path and no salary increase unless they go to management.

review_title: Software Engineer - Positive experience with caveats
pros:
1. Ericsson is a value led organization, its sincerity towards inclusive networks is reflected in its work culture
2. Everyone from the lower rungs to the very top is approachable and respectful of your opinions no matter how young and inexperienced you are
3. The best work-life balance you will find anywhere
4. Monthly awards and yearly bonuses on top of generous leave packages
5. A Brandon itself, especially in terms of Radio communications
cons:
1. Average salaries are a worry
2. It is known to be over-cautious in its goals, setting low targets which hampers it's potential
Advice to Management
Ericsson is a great company. You must be ready to take greater risks and strive to grab the next big thing before it is off the plate - IoT being a case in point a bit of aggressive marketing would do no harm either.

pros: The best thing the company has to offer to employees is great health insurance benefits, this is what keeps people working there.
cons:
The company has failed to secure new contracts, so the culture is you never know from one day to the next if you will have a job! Ericsson also has a policy of 80/20 which means 80% of the work has to be done offshore and they move to push everything the can to India so this displaces American workers. They require employees to log hours they do not work and if you do not do this you are placed on a list to be laid off.
Advice to Management

review_title: Ericsson was a great place to work while it lasted
pros: Ericsson has some of the best benefits of any company out there, seriously gold star. Their pay was comparable or better than other companies. My coworkers were smart and diligent; it was a good environment for achieving results and learning new technologies.
cons:
They made some very bad moves, especially in the Media division. They bought part of Microsoft to enhance their position in the IPTV space and then let that management team run wild. They overspent on a next generation cloud based IPTV platform, which over promised features and undelivered on results. It was too late to the market and didn’t deliver much over the previous products.
Advice to Management
Management is doing the right things now; they are trying to get the business and finances in order. Unfortunately there were so many mistakes made in the past 4-5 years it’s very painful to see the company torn apart and all of the layoffs. They have to get to a steady state; nobody can operate at 100% when they are constantly worried about getting laid off.

pros:
Flexible working hours as long work is done within expected time frame.
Relatively easy and smooth promotion for entry level engineers level 1 to get up to level 3.
cons:
No work life balance. Weekly work load of 55-60 hours average.
Below market average salary.
No overtime paid, not even time off for extra 40+ hours worked weekly.
Zero percent salary increase during 2 consecutive years to all employees due "low profit in business".
Slow time to market response to customers due slow, long and lenghty internal processes.
No long term incentive plan to keep employees.
No promotion or recognition given to engineers to achieve level 4, just few get there but takes long long time.
Barrier for career growth to engineers level 4, this is as far as you can get to.
Performance measured as Below average, Meets expectation and exceeds expectation. There is an extremely low cap to limit max number of employees can get Exceeds expectation, no matter how much well you have done in the entire year.
No collaborative work environment, since everyone is competing to be the highlight within the department/team.
Extremely high overhead count.
Upper layer Management keeps exchanging chairs, positions and titles but no actual work is done.
Too many processes, bureocracy and paperwork.
Lack of training.
Advice to Management
Encourage and inforce work life balance.
Increase salaries of engineers/techinical employees, not overhead.
Paid overtime or offer time off for 40+ extra hours worked weekly.
Simplify internal processes and listen to customers for a better market response time. 
Establish a long term incentive plan to keep good employees.
Review promotion process to allow engineers career growth to level 5 and above.
Remove performance measurement based on no cap for exceeds expectation. Everyone should exceed expectations and get an exceeds. Do you want your company only to meet expectations?
Encourage collaborative work environment with less competition
Reduce overhead count.
No more upper layer management exchanging chairs, positions and titles.
Simplify processes and paperwork.
Offer more training to employees.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

location: São Paulo, São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
+ There are very good professionals to work with and learn from

+ People are very respectful

+ Opportunity to code in C++, which is rarely seen today in Brazil

+ Extra hours and "on-call" are correctly paid, which means you can increase your income substantially when you work more
cons:
+ Management in general have little knowledge of software development business

+ Lack of knowledge of software makes managers approach innovation and career development of subordinates in a KPI-driven manner, without actually being capable of understanding what is really going on with people and projects

+ Very competent people might never have a real raise in their salaries because managers are not capable of recognizing their contributions, probably because they are blind to see anything which is not in their metrics (a consequence of not knowing the software business)

+ Products use out-dated technologies and there is no culture to foster innovation on this aspect

+ In general, technical staff sees career development programs as boring, because they no longer rely on line managers and do not believe there will a reward for those who work hard on what matters

+ You can see incompetent people climbing in their careers by means of good relationships and tricking performance numbers, and when become managers appear to have no real interest for productive stuff (like raising competence of technical staff, recognizing talents or ease the life of workers doing a good job), but only projects that can render some good visibility

+ There is a trend in technical staff for migrating to tasks that are less and less related to software development, as if they are abandoning the interest for the real business (because it is not as rewarding as doing spreadsheets)

+ It is frequent to hear a discourse about the importance of quality, and you see a lot of measuring of quality metrics, but little action or smart conclusions

+ Most of the technical staff is now outsourced and composed of more junior professionals, which are visibly less competent on average, something that obviously impacts quality of deliverables, but there is not much evidence that management realizes that or even cares about it

+ Not only managers, but in general, people are missing the bigger picture, and forgot that quality is not going to improve by only measuring it, because that requires action and investment
Advice to Management
I cannot see how the software design unit in Brazil is ever going to thrive having a management that has no real interest on software. I have a feeling that most people on the area (specially on management) are there only to cash good money while Ericsson does not sink.
It is a shame, because otherwise it would e a top notch place to work.
Leaving the negative points beside, this company as a beautiful culture and might be one of the last employers that actually seem to care about something else but making money to share-holders.
There is the inevitable presence of people that are going to take advantage of this just to slack until retirement.
However, you can also see professionals that really love what they do and are in a mission to serve society with the best of their skills. These employees should be better taken care of.

pros:
1. Good learning, variety of exposure to various domains.
2. Good opportunities locally as well as worldwide.
cons:
1. No more a focused and innovative company.
2. Unable to keep up pace with changing industry, as a result of which it is bleeding losses over losses every quarter since 2014.
3. Politics at highest management affect Engineers.
4. Company is confused now what to do and what not to do to stop the bleeding.
5. Unable to find a single visionary who can take Ericsson back to its golden era ; all because of internal politics.
6. Agile is used to micr-manage people.
7. No work life balance. WFH is strictly prohibited as many locations and is granted based on manager's discretion.
Advice to Management
1. Hire right people to do right job and remove people who are making the organization bleed while exploiting the organization.
2. Find suitable CEO who can guide Ericsson on what it should be doing.
3. Cut off all non-performing BUs/Segments once for all and retain only future growth areas.
4. Remove lethargic and slow moving people (there are plenty of them still)

pros:
Excellent work life balance, especially for women employees. Good company to retire with.
Flat hierarchical structure, where people can reach out anyone at anytime. 
Few projects use cutting edge technologies providing more career development and growth.
Excellent recognition and rewards to the people who perform well in the projects.
Excellent people to interact with, thus creating a spirit to work for the company.
cons:
Salary hike is not consistent across the years leading to demotivate the employees. The new hires are paid way too high when compared to the ones already working out their soul for Ericsson.
Work load is not shared equally between the team members.
Advice to Management
Management is doing their best at Ericsson, listening to each one's queries, but they can be little more transparent.
Hiring needs to be more strict as many new hires are lacking much technical knowledge and confidence. They are paid so high and I feel they are not upto the mark.
Interview process needs to be formulated and made strict. An interview panel across a Region can be a way forward. The Interview Panel needs to be paid for their extra efforts in getting the right candidate and training had to be given to those who actually take interviews. A tough and a rigid interview must happen to filter the right candidates.

review_title: Good company with great benefits but finding a way forward.
pros: Good company that has a global presence and seeks to improve itself and employees. Education and health are pushed regularly and there it is a great experience if you can work on the Plano TX campus or connect withe the Santa Clara CA Teams. I am sure there are other great groups to connect with but these are the folks I interfaced with the most.
cons:
Seemingly unstable environment as there is always a lot of change and have been a number of Layoffs or RIFs over the past 2 years. This leaves many with a constant concern that they "could be next". 
This will change over time as the industry is seeing some great changes and companies like Ericsson are trying to adjust and stay on top while being pressured by lots of new competitors.
Advice to Management
Provide stability for the front-line teams, the constant change is creating a culture of concern and fear in some which is so unhealthy. This will push away top talent into more stable work environments, whether they are new and looking or existing talent and deciding on a way forward.

review_title: Cutting edge software development if you want it. Cloud, Docker, Gradle, Groovy, you name it.
pros:
Benefits, Family oriented, work from home options.

If you need help or training, just ask because it is not seen as a weakness but as a way to grow the talent and the teams. Other organizations I have worked for have always considered this a weakness, but not Ericsson. We all learn together and sharing through brown bags and learning lunches is encouraged.
cons:
Software engineers are often shuffling between 2 projects, sometimes 3 because of the high rate of our customers wants and needs. The benefit however here, is that you are constantly growing and learning !

Training is provided but you really have to push and ask for it if there is a need (not really a con, its expected you should ask if you need help)

In North America and Canada, there is a bit too many non technical managers I would say, but this stems from the fact previously about many projects, sometimes simultaneously that your working on as a software engineer, so you sometimes get the feeling you have 2 or 3 managers, but in reality there's always only 1 direct report relationship that you have in your career.
Advice to Management
Less management.

pros: Smart and dedicated engineers as colleagues, good work-life balance, transparency in sharing technical know-how, very good benefits (for a non-Internet company).
cons:
Ericsson is no longer a wireless technology leader - the Asian vendors have caught up and in many instances overtaken E///. The next two years will be painful as 5G money won't start coming in until 2019. All major decisions are taken in Stockholm by Swedes, limited career prospects at a remote site. Compensation is below par for the Bay Area. Media division is next on the chopping block. Morale diminishing after every quarterly report.
Advice to Management
It should be obvious to management why they are unable to retain talent in Silicon Valley

review_title: Good people but hindered by internal bureaucracy - giant company syndrome
pros: Flexible working is great, and the size of the company offers potential for movement.
cons:
Very difficult to progress initiatives due to internal systems not supporting the staff. Invisible HR and poor IT support. Lots of restaffing at higher levels with no apparent difference to staff. A lot of staff don't value communication and emails can go unanswered for days.
Advice to Management
Take more interest in the real-word problems that staff face and stop revising high level strategies that provoke navel gazing. Lessen the rigid rules that stop initiatives being developed.

review_title: A Decent Company - Going through a transition
pros:
Friendly, professional atmosphere, which attracts decent employees. 
Ericsson culture values work-life balance (at least in Product Development).
Good facilities in some offices (e.g. gym, restaurant, library etc). 
Fair compensation.
cons:
Ericsson is going through strategic transitions at the moment due to tough market conditions - so may not be a very secure option.
In struggling with profits, often seems to be overly concerned with costs - sometimes to the detriment of productivity (e.g. lack of investment in equipment, face to face meetings and sometimes training).
Advice to Management
Need to be disruptive in technology.
Don't just follow the technical trends.
Don't spin buzzwords - although I think the new CEO realizes this!

pros:
- Somewhat flexible working hours
- Great work/life balance
- No pressure whatsoever
- Friendly co-workers
cons:
- Mindgames and politics within the department could steer your whole career in an unpredictable fashion for years
- Stale management unfit for the role at their positions for many, many years 
- Lack of leadership by example, complex and heavy hierarchy involving a lot of corporate overhead
- Large-corporation symptoms such as inertia to quick action and innovation
- Serious lack of motivation in colleagues that used to be very ambitious and highly-skilled, but all drive was sucked out of them for as short as 10 years time, wearing them out and turning them into corporate drones
- Lack of a clear reward system because no matter what you do you are treated as average
Advice to Management
- Lead by example, experience and deserved privileges, not hierarchy.
- Value and reward motivated and ambitious employees, do not prioritize corporate agenda by turning them into corporate drones.

review_title: Good for life/work balance, but a lot of cons
pros:
I initially worked for a company that was bought by Ericsson, most of us from creative rather then corporate backgrounds. A few of the perks were

- modern offices
- flexible work hours
- working from home
- good, relaxed atmosphere, surrounded with fun people from different backgrounds and countries, very international
- paid overtime
cons:
For a communications company the internal communications are beyond bad, finding any information in a jungle of acronyms that nobody knows what they stand for is rather untransparent and difficult.

- being from a creative/media background there isn't many options for moving up in the company
- shockingly low salaries/no salary increases/no bonuses (in the UK at least)
- high staff turnover
- a lot of offshoring and redundancies
- HR is slow and unorganised, hard to find information
- poor IT infrastructure, you're not being provided the necessary tools to do your job properly and getting anything fixed is a lengthy process
- the employees aren't shown enough respect or that they are valued by the company
Advice to Management
Value your employees

pros: Great healthcare benefits, fun place to work, schedule flexibility, (with the right manager). Pay is competitive with market rates. Paid time off is one of the best in the area.
cons:
Very unfair advancement opportunities. If you do not have or have not established a personal relationship with a member of management or executive team, do not expect to be advanced. These opportunities are only granted to friends and family while management forces its employees to believe it is their sole responsibility to map out their career. However, it has been proven time and time again: An employees career path is well established prior to the employees presenting their career desires.
Advice to Management
Use credential: Educations, experience and knowledge for considerations of advancement opportunities versus relationships. Monitor managers' selection and appointment to assure there is not favoritism in these appointments. At least question a managers decision to appoint the same person(s) each time.

pros:
Good Pay, but you will have to work a lot of hours/callout etc to get it
Flexible working hours (at least in my area)
cons:
Large amount of work has been shifted to India. They have no clue how things in the UK work and seem unwilling to learn. They made lots of staff in the UK redundant to move to a cheaper and entirely less competent workforce

Awful IT systems that are managed by the same group in India (expect lots of "Please do the needful" Indian-isms). They love acronyms and hashtags!

Management are clueless, there's a fear/blame culture seemingly stemming from upper management. 

While hours are flexible, you will be expected to do a lot of admin work in your own time

Lots of red-tape, lots of project managers, lots of pointless meetings

Benefits package is useless. Share scheme has been stopped, perks-at-work is normally more expense than I can get as a normal consumer. Pension isn't great.

No promotions, no incentive to work hard. Bonus scheme paid a whole 1% last year

Pay rises have been awful (or non-existent) for years, yet the CEO and upper management take home a kings bounty
Advice to Management
Move work back from EGI, cheap doesn't always mean good. Invest in the areas that need work, listen to your staff and stop witch hunts and the blame culture

pros: The company I worked for before was bought by Ericsson, and everything started out well with a forward-looking management team and the will to invest in new technologies. Since then, however, we have been hit by redundancies and increasing bureaucracy. Modern offices, nice location, great colleagues who are generally intelligent, lively and very overqualified for the job. Some of the content is really interesting as work is for a variety of broadcasters/clients. Laid-back culture for the most part. Decent benefits such as flexible working and the possibility of working from home.
cons:
Pay is shockingly low among non-managers and even middle managers, though the company likes to tell us it is in line with industry standards. Management training is almost non-existent, and there seem to be far too many people employed at higher levels with incomprehensible job titles and functions. Managers are also sometimes expected to be account managers rather than people managers, meaning that staff can be overlooked. Staff turnover on some teams is so bad it is like a revolving door, and work/life balance varies greatly depending on which team you are on. Some jobs are extremely monotonous. Many people come to rely on overtime money because the base salaries are so bad. The IT systems are impenetrable, and dealing with other teams that are all in other countries because of offshoring (e.g. for expenses or HR, for example) can be difficult and bureaucratic. Team spirit has decreased since we were bought, and retention is increasingly difficult. Opportunities for advancement do exist, but generally not within teams - you would have to change job role internally.
Advice to Management
Try to show the staff that they are valued. Pay them properly, for a start. They are generally an excellent and talented bunch of people, and it's a real shame that good employees leave with such frequency.
6 people found this review helpful

review_title: Best Company to word for when there is work.
pros: Managers who Care about the employee, Benefits are outstanding, Layoff treatment was outstanding. Ericsson North America. Good work rewarded when possible. Training online for multiple positions and functions via employee produced and external training companies. Many responsible full time employees.
cons:
Management employees are over worked which leaves less time to find contracts for the company. Recent management seems to be using only contract workers.
Advice to Management
Temporary work force is not the way to a great team. Keep up the great Employee compensation/benefits. Strive to find more long term contracts to keep your worker bees busy and expanding. Find more contracts that stage for the next contract. Give your middle management some relief if possible.

pros: . It has strong corporate governance and a history of being able to adapt to changing markets. It has a presence in many countries and understands the need for diversity. Ericsson is a market leader, in fact likely the market leader, in telecoms equipment.
cons:
It also has problems that large companies tend to have. It will take you many years to advance, no matter how ambitious you are. It is led by large shareholders who have a very narrow idea of what modern business practices are, and a board that is mostly unable to understand disruptions like the internet, so it has a big problem innovating. Since it is the market leader it has a lot of competitive advantages, but those are mostly used to create a barrier to entry instead of innovating.
Advice to Management
The corporate culture has a bit of a Swedish bent, which isn't necessarily bad, but it is really conservative. If you're looking for fiercely competitive business practices with an impatient, and highly talented culture, you may want to look somewhere else. If you're looking for a solid performer, that dominates its market, has collegial atmostphere and room to grow, then you could do a whole lot worse than Ericsson.

review_title: Awful IT systems, no development, no training, managers with no understanding of effective management
pros: Nothing particularly great, I worked in the subtitling department of Ericsson Broadcast and Media services so content could be interesting.
cons:
No learning or development, no budget for professional qualifications, no in-house training.
Very poor middle to senior management within the subtitling arm - people who had been bought in when the BBC sold off their department were lacking in soft skills and motivation.
Ericsson HR is outsourced - this led to the incorrect salary being quoted to my bank when applying for a mortgage. Ericsson were unable to provide my current employer with proof that I had worked there. I was placed on the wrong tax code since leaving due to Ericsson HR ineptitude, and have been overpaying tax for much of the past financial year. 

Horrendous company, I had not quite realised how poor the training, opportunities, facilities and services were until I had left and started in a company with none of these issues.
Advice to Management
Implement 360 reviews again, but without the option for the individual to self-select who supplies their reviews. This will show the senior management (client relationship manager type level) who have none of the skills required for their roles. Review pay, it is below market average and not competitive. Review pay of legacy BBC contract employees - disproportionately high.

cons:
ltant in Bangalore
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
1. work from home 
2. very good cafeteria - tasty and economic 
3. cultural events
4. promotional gifts
5. team outing/lunch/dinner - from project as well as from your business group 
6. outing with family
7. training - internal as well as external and course fee reimbursement facility
8. good cab service
9. phone/internet/medical bill/medical checkup/mobile handset claims
10. good infrastructure and peace of mind
11. onsite facilities as much as you want 
12. No micro management, no one will ask what are you doing every hour
13. No dress code mandatory for non-customer facing roles
14. Good salary but hike depends on profit
15. Free desk policy - sit and work where ever you want in the campus
16. Good play area - carroms, table tennis, mini golf, Foosball etc
17. CCDs new Coffee/Tea machines in all floors - free coffee/tea ;) 
18. Rare after hour/weekend works
19. Leaves are always approved unless there is any critical work that depends entirely on you
20. Infrastructure including restrooms are well maintained
Cons
1. No proper induction training for new joins
2. Lacking big budget long term projects 
3. Management people are need to be more responsive to the emails
4. You may feel Indian work culture(politics, favorism, ego etc) sometimes because of some people who worked in Indian IT companies for long time and joined Ericsson after that.
5. Mentor/TL should be a kind of person who inspires the new joins. Not just assign the work and ask to resolve it by giving no proper guidelines.
Advice to Management
Keep up good work. Please try to get more long term projects so that employees will get more confidence to stay here for long. Billing emails should not be send at the last moment if so, mistakes can be avoided.

pros: Traditional workplace with no surprises
cons:
Unprofessional confrontation by senior management
Inability to deliver payroll on time without proper notice by HR
Unrealistic expectations of job, tasks versus resources given
Inability to differentiate work from personal time by senior management
Toxic work environment and no guidance
Little to no mental health support or awareness
Little to no opportunities for advancement
Below average training and onboarding process
Advice to Management
I was never treated this horribly at any company of any size, let alone expecting such a giant corporate to be so unprofessional. Before asking why employees leave out of the blue, maybe ask if senior management is actually doing their jobs in providing adequate training, support, and follow-up with subordinates. Working at this company has caused me my mental health and wellbeing, and this is not the first time something similar has happened.

Just to clarify, the local branch has still not apologized or acknowledged their mistakes, and some were a clear violation of local labour laws.

pros: and
cons:
20 Mar 2017 - Network Operations Field Technician 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Best thing about this company... BENEFITS! Their benefit package was amazing! Pay was pretty good, too, on top of that.
Cons
For the last few years there have been one or two layoffs each year, which made going to work extra stressful. There also seemed to be a lot of groups and people that didn't want to work together for fear of sharing something that would make them irrelevant, so communication started to get pretty poor. Ultimately, all of this was due to shifting contracts and inability to get new contracts. Lack of work for the company meant less need for employees.
Advice to Management
Know the jobs better of the people working below you and be willing to listen to them. Sometimes knowing the work being done and listening to the people doing it can help solve some problems in different ways than are discussed in board rooms.

review_title: Could be such a great place to work...
pros: Large company, lots of resources at your disposal. People really seem to care about the outcome and the work that they do. Good managers and mostly good people to work with and work for.
cons:
Management drives value-less initiatives. Compensation doesn't keep up with the market. Always have to look over your shoulder because you never know when the next round of layoffs are. Tough place to be successful with all of the internal politics. Little to no growth potential - Career development is hard to come by unless you have an outstanding manager who at every turn is willing to stick his/her neck out for you, or you work in one of the target growth areas and can prove among the masses that you deserve a promotion.
Advice to Management
Fix the internal struggles. Identify career paths for employees so they know what there options are and how to get where they want to be.

review_title: How to go nuts in a short time...
pros: Reasonable per diem, good hotels.
cons:
The company senior management is good at pointing fingers at you, but on the other hand, no support is provided. It was never clear if it is a company strategy to win competition at all costs, meaning, having no profit...and after that, cut resources from project...easy to check, just take a look on the project perfomances all over Caribbe and Central America...plus...south America...
Other major problem that I surely noticed is that Ericsson senior management is not prepared to confront the customer...even if it´s clearly the customer fault, Ericsson will not confront the customer...
Advice to Management
Senior management, you should be more with your team, not remotely following up with the Project Managers, but certainly, be on customer site and support your team.

cons:
ltant
23 Feb 2017 - Senior Consultant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
The best reason to work at Ericsson is because it's a job.
Cons
Could care less about their top employees. They don't even pay their expenses in a timely manner. After months of claiming that they are still fixing an accounting system they still haven't paid what amounts to double digits. Their credit card never even begins to cover monthly costs of travelling around the globe. Additionally when they have paid it is always late and it is up to the employee to pay late fees.
Advice to Management
Pay attention to your employees. You have some great ones, but no one seems to care.Everyone runs around like a chicken with its head cut off and there is no direction. There is no one to even complain too. And don't ever pay your own expenses. It will be months before you see them.

Technology Day - Waste of Time & Resources,

Start Listening to your subordinates.

review_title: Another giant tech company but culture is not like the ones in US
pros: Good Work Environment, Relaxed Work Culture (Typical of Swedish), Good Colleagues, Global work opportunity (specially if you are in Service Sector), Right place for someone who is happy with slow and average growth in career.
cons:
1. Climbing up the ladders is difficult in management unless you speak the local language and come from similar cultural background. Only having good people skill and technical knowledge is not good enough.
2. Being young and being a consistent high performer does not mean promotions are easy and pay rise is also high. Slow and Easy going approach for everyone. More of Scandinavian work culture.
3. Too many methodologies, too many work approach for the same job in multiple teams. Low level management does not show much concern to unify the overlapped items. 
4. Decision making sometimes takes a long time which is frustrating and affects others in the organization. It reduces the productivity.
Advice to Management
1. Make the high performing engineers feel empowered, recognize them, evaluate them. They are the core of core of your company. 
2. Provide training and opportunities for upcoming talents who has proper career vision. Support them, build them, they will lead you to a better growth. 
3. Improve the retention rate (mainly the high performers).
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: The Higher the Better (in all aspects)
pros: When I joined it on 2004, its culture was the most attractive to me. Its working environment was one of the most innovative and trustworthy I had been experiencing (before that I've been with a dozen other MNC). The processes were strong. The Management was transparent and close to front line. The team was friendly and supportive and customer oriented.
cons:
Under Hans Vestberg, the Company has been getting less and less innovative and more and more political at all levels (less doers, more players/talkers). The Management was less transparent and more deceiving in their management style. Hence the constant downward annual result trend throughout Hans' CEO years. 

Benefits wise, it was sloppy at entry and start of mid level. And speed up fast when getting higher in career ladder.
Advice to Management
Get back to its original and core culture of an innovative company the fastest possible.

Repor

pros:
Great place to work with good development opportunities (if you make it your business). 
Globally looking, it's a Swedish style management (consensus seeking at lower mgmt levels). 
Easy people to work with opportunity to travel globally.
cons:
Could be over administrative at times. 
Not as efficient at meetings and decision taking (Swedish consensus seeking style can be frustrating at times). 
Lack of independent review of local management WoW and HR policies, expose danger of "Cowboy style management" at local companies 
Limited progression opportunities at local companies (if you want to progress, make sure you find your way to talent list pool). 
Sometimes networking could be a key to your way forward (sometimes it could be "who you know, not what you know").
Advice to Management
After major re-org, allow some time for organisational adjustment. Basically, don't do major re-org every year. At Business Unit and Regional level, we have seen major re-orgs in past couple of years, and people have hard time following who is who any more. 
Celebrate teams success and share company's (local and global strategy) at half yearly, or quarterly all employee meetings. Praise go's a long way. First we had 2 per year, then 1 per year, and I don't even rememver when was the last one at GSC in Bucharest. 
Improve work benefit: "If you pay peanuts, you get monkeys". It's not all about pay. Flexible working hours count a lot, especially in big and busy city like Bucharest. 
Ensure E/// attracts top talent, not only for TOP250 management positions, but also to for the key technical roles. Don't be training ground for other competitor companies (basically people leave for "greener fields" after they acquire some knowledge). 
It's all about communication and innovation, right? So work on team building and company comradery. Ensure budget for at least once a year social/sports event, dinner/night out, or similar. People basically don't know each other past several desks away or other team members. It;s hard to share experiences and knowledge. 
Eliminate silo mentality and enable "one Ericsson" culture.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful
Share
Repor

pros: Great benefits and some amazing people. Working on a campus provides nice amenities.
cons:
Management and executive leadership do not reflect the diversity of the people they're leading; if you aren't in with the right people, you have no hope of moving forward. Misogyny and racism, while hopefully accidental, are not addressed appropriately. The appearance of inappropriate relationships between leadership and staff occurs often and is not addressed. There is lip service paid to diversity and inclusion in North America, but there seems to be a disconnect from HQ in Plano to the Overland Park office. Managers make jokes about people they've laid off, and disparage employees in front of other employees. 

I have noticed, reading through these reviews, that Ericsson responds nicely to the positive reviews. A response to a negative review, any of the reviews that have brought up negative experiences, would show potential and current employees that Ericsson does care about their employees and wants to ensure a safe, healthy, productive, and positive environment for them all.
Advice to Management
Management should be held as examples to their employees. 

Fear and intimidation are not effective long-term.

Management skip-levels are important, but only effective if leadership fosters an inclusive environment.

review_title: A shell of what it once was
pros:
Decent 401k.
Good medical benefits.
Flexible working hours, no time clock.
cons:
The past years have not been kind to Ericsson.

1. Little to no promotion opportunities.
The company prefers hiring externally for any senior position. This is a terrible policy as it allows for little to no upward mobility for existing employees. 

2. Awful, terrible management.
See item 1. The senior and management resources brought in, have little to no understanding of the company and its ways of working. They are often colleagues and friends of other senior resources... I can name you half a dozen Alcatel-Lucent folks all brought in. This nepotism is destroying the company. They have no vision, no drive, and no interest in improving anything or doing any actual work.

3. Benefits are lacking.
The stock purchase plan was canceled in Jan 2017. That's a 7.5% pay cut. It's not canceled for senior management of course, even though they ran the company into the ground.

4. Constant layoffs.
This has been ongoing for 2 years now and there it no end in sight. Every few months your team loses 2-4 people. Sounds like a place you want to work?

5. Too much overhead and management layers.
See also item 1. Despite promises to do something about this for 12+ months, there is no change. When layoffs come, regular emplyees are let go. It's never the layer upon layer of directors and VPs that are axed. We have VPs reporting to VPs reporting to VPs.... I'm not kidding. With little to no direct reports. How is that even possible? But hey, that's what you get with terrible management.

6. Terrible processes.
Need to order something? Need to bring an overseas resource in? Need to find a pen? Need to fix a problem with a tool or time entry? Good luck. I hope you have 2 hours each day for the coming 5 days to beg, borrow, and steal to get the help you need.

7. Pay for anyone not "grandfatherered" into a big salary or hired from the outside
Some folks make enormous sums of money. Mainly the countless directors and VPs that are breaking the back of the company (see up)... 300K a year type of money. The rank and file employees, some make great money if they've been here through the boom days of the late 1990s. Other, younger employees who were hired as a regular employee and not a "super important" manager (see item 2 above) are stuck making 70K a year with an annual raise of 1-2%. Good luck ever catching up.

8. No strategy or vision.
We are wildly flailing our arms trying to catch buzzwords. One day we have to do "cloud." The next it is declared we're going to be "Agile." Then next week it's "devops" and "the internet of things." Meanwhile, in reality, we've had our own cloud product ECE (Ericsson Cloud Environment) that's been in development for 3+ years and has yet to work or even be sold. Agile exists only in the minds of our clueless managers. Our product catalog contains hundreds if not thousands of products that are obsolete and don't sell. Management makes their fat paychecks and figures they can hang around another 2-3 years doing nothing, and they simply don't care.

employee_title: Engagement Manager In Latin America (IT Presales)
review_title: Engagement Manager in Latin America (IT Presales)
pros:
Good overall line of Products (for telecommunication industry)
Good compensation and bonus (mine was 1/2 yearly base salary in 2016)
Flexible working hours and home office
cons:
No management culture : middle managers are mainly dedicated to administrative tasks and do not move upwards nor motivate their subordinates.
Very administrative matrix structure : much time is lost in coordination/escalation instead of delivering value to the customer
Matrix cross-country organization is very badly handled : no team meetings, no horizontal, ascending and descending communication inside the teams.
In Latin America : there is no meritocracy; good networking and politics count much more than good results to grow there (and to stay there!)
Ericsson Latin America is NOT a Swedish company but a Brazilian company (good to know before joining Sao Paulo office...)
Lack of innovation mindset
Low capacity to challenge themselves (no lessons learnt, no capitalization)
Advice to Management
Advice to Corporate Top Management : stop looking only at the top or bottom line of each region. Enforce corporate governance locally at each level (HR, management...)

ltant in Frankfurt am Main
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Good long term vision, work/life balance quite OK, outstanding and brilliant colleagues. Management style of most managers is quite relaxed.
Cons
Too much internal politics -- whole departments suffer because someone somewhere executed a power play to keep their VP title and ownership of a once successful product. Too much bureaucracy and unnecessary process. Poor execution of client projects: they take too long, are too expensive, and in the end suffer from poor quality due to rushing to meet overdue deadlines. It seems like the preferred solution to many problems is "throw more people at it".
Advice to Management
Don't let financial folks run a tech company.

pros: Reasonable work-life balance. Not very hierarchical corporate culture. Many encounters with people from other cultures.
cons:
Very slow decision making. Complicated organization with unclear responsibilities and decision processes. Managers are allowed to stay too long in their positions and eventually loose pace and focus on the business. Poor communication between different functions, "silo" structure.
Advice to Management
Replace several top and middle management layers. Implement a simple and clear accountability structure. Simpler performance measurements.

review_title: Great Teamwork Poor Uppler/ Exec Management
pros: Money and Benefits are great - Team atmosphere in business units is high. The company is so disorganized that if you like a challenge, you are often able to take on projects and tasks that are out of your original/main scope and migrate throughout different business unites based upon the successes that you may not have been able to attain if left only to a tightly managed single tract.
cons:
Flapping around like a fish out of water trying to plan for the future instead of driving the market towards that future.
Advice to Management
Please groom successful leaders in engineering and operations to migrate into upper management . The board members are clueless as to where the companies money is spent and wasted. How can you drive efficiency if you have never worked in the business?
